CulturalObject.Description: This is the base of a 16th century ivory saltcellar or box. A series of figures can be seen surrounding the base, and supporting the bowl. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A model canoe, carved out of wood, with triangular knobs at the brow and stern. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs

A glass bottle, encased in leatherwork and woven fibre, and with a leather covered stopper. This style of woven and tooled leatherwork resembles so-called Mandingo leatherwork, predominating among Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Glass; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This is a whip, with a carved wooden handle attached to links of iron chain. The handle has a typical Sierra Leonean carved head with a segmented neck and ridged hairstyle.
A beaded necklace, consisting of a twisted fibre cord with five orange carnelian beads, four round ivory beads, and three round wooden beads.
CulturalObject.Materials: Stone; Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Bone, Ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: A powder horn, likely for storing gun powder. Either end is wrapped in tooled leather, with bands of woven leather and grass. This type of decoration is commonly known as Mandingo. Mandingo, here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre; Bone, ivory, horn

CulturalObject.Description: A conical hat, made from coiled natural fibre. It has a wide brim, decorated with dark woven stripes and four strips of leather leading from a leather button at the top point, down to the rim. The Fula hat was donated to the British Museum alongside a gown and stringed instrument, all collected by Thomas Whitfield. Thomas Whitfield was in Sierra Leone between 1828 and the late 1850s, and is more commonly associated with his collections of flora and fauna.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A model canoe, carved out of wood. It has been stained black, after which an intricate geometric pattern was engraved into the base. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs
A square bottomed basket, made from woven light brown, and dark brown, bamboo.
A hat, made from coiled grass, or raffia. It has a wide brim, decorated with dark brown stripes. The crown is wrapped in a thick bundle of raffia.

A likely pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have layered leather soles, with a wide tooled leather strap and a large domed bottom. Mandingo was often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.

A powder horn, likely for storing gun powder. Either end is wrapped in bands of tooled leather. It is attached to a plaited strap, with tassels. This type of decoration is commonly known as Mandingo. Mandingo, here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, horn

CulturalObject.Description: A bridle, for controlling a horse when riding, made from plaited lengths of leather, knotted together. There is a tasselled fringed sewn onto the section of leather that would have hung across the horses forehead.

A sword, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
A group of 19 arrows, with iron arrow heads, and cane shafts. The British Museum records notes that they are poisoned. The arrows are contained in a tooled leather cylindrical case, or quiver.

A group of 19 arrows, with iron arrow heads, and cane shafts. The British Museum records notes that they are poisoned. The arrows are contained in a tooled leather cylindrical case, or quiver. This entry refers to the quiver lid.
A group of 19 arrows, with iron arrow heads, and cane shafts. The British Museum records notes that they are poisoned. The arrows are contained in a tooled leather cylindrical case, or quiver.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A tooled leather quiver, with a carrying strap. It has a leather cap, and contains a number of arrows with iron tips.

A leather pouch with flaps decorated with tooled and painted geometric design. It has a leather loop at each corner, and one at the fastening, to which are attached leather tassels. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo leatherwork.

This is a 16th century spoon, carved out of a single piece of ivory. A crocodile is carved on top of the handle in high relief, and the central section of the handle has a double-eight loop, with a snake on either side. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

This is a 16th century spoon, carved out of a single piece of ivory. It has a slender stem handle, with spiralled decoration, and a thin, leaf-shaped, bowl. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

This is a 16th century ivory saltcellar or box. It is very ornate, with a series of seated figures in high relief surrounding the base, and man-eating crocodiles on the lid. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

This is a 16th century ivory saltcellar or box. It is very ornate, with a series of seated figures in high relief surrounding the base, and man-eating crocodiles on the lid. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid and bound with bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork, in a Mandingo style. Mandingo, here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid and bound with bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork, in a Mandingo style. Mandingo, here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is particularly unusual as the mask is wearing a top-hat; European top hats became a symbols of prestige among elites in the late 19th century Sierra Leone. She is complete with a black-dyed raffia fringe. This item was acquired at the Colonial and Indian Exhibition in London, 1886.
A bangle made out of elephant pad, inlaid with a row of white metal dots.
A bangle made out of elephant pad, inlaid with a row of white metal dots. This item was acquired at the Colonial and Indian Exhibition in London, 1886.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. The British Museum records note that this figure used to have an iron band around its waist.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Collector); Colonial and Indian Exhibition 1886

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example came to the British Museum from Captain Soden in 1893, and represents a male figure, standing upright.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example has been damaged, only the head remains. It has a leaf-like pattern running across its head, and what is likely to be the remains of a chair, or throne, in which the figure was seated.

This is a Temne wooden female figure. She has a typical segmented neck and a striped rectangle of cotton around her waist. Though she resembles a so-called minsereh, or min, figure, these terms are traditionally associated with female wooden figures from the south of Sierra Leone; this example originates in the north. The collector of this figure was Captain George Arthur Williams who made a journey into the interior of Sierra Leone in 1892 to visit Samori Ture, the founder of an inland Muslim state who was at war with the French colonial authorities. During is journey he passed through Tinkatupa, a Temne chiefdom, north of Port Loko. This figure is thought to have come from Tinkatupa.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ ritual equiptment
CulturalObject.Description: A neck ornament with a leather charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It is made from Mandingo leatherwork, which is traditionally associated with Muslim elites in the North of Sierra Leone. Their are four sebe attached to a black leather chord; the two larger leather rectangular boxes have a tooled flower design. Sebe/sebbeh, like these, usually contain Quranic scripts.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ ritual equiptment
CulturalObject.Description: A pair of bracelets, each baring a either charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. They are made from Mandingo leatherwork, which is traditionally associated with Muslim elites in the North of Sierra Leone. They consist of a thin braided leather strap, holding a small rectangular box.
A sample of steatite stone.
A set of four cone-shell ornaments, for weaving into the hair.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ ritual equiptment
CulturalObject.Description: These are recorded as a pair of charms. They consist of a round piece of shell attached to a leather thong. These items entered the collection alongside a set of Mandingo leatherwork amulets, or sebe/sebbeh, seen in the picture.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, Ivory, tooth; Shell

CulturalObject.Description: This is a screwdriver for a flintlock gun. It has a wooden handle with knob carved on end, decorated with carved geometric patterns, and a flat metal blade extending out from handle, with L-shaped prong.
A small wooden mortar and pestle, for grinding snuff. The pestle is rounded at one end, and has a flat spoon at the other. It resembles larger mortars and pestles for pounding rice.
A small wooden mortar and pestle, for grinding snuff. The pestle is rounded at one end, and has a flat spoon at the other. It resembles larger mortars and pestles for pounding rice.
A set or four open bangles, made from a twisted pieces of iron.
A group of six orange carnelian beads.
A wooden pipe used for smoking tobacco. It has been stained white with clay.
A wooden pipe used for smoking tobacco. It has been stained white with clay.
A carved, wooden, female figure, seated on a round stool. She is holding a bowl with both hands, and has a segmented neck.

This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example stands on a round base, and has a typical segmented neck.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical five-lobed hairstyle, with geometric panels. She is complete with black-dyed raffia. The mask was accessioned along with the tunic [BM:Af.1901.722.10.b] and leggings [BM:Af.1901.722.10.c and d - now lost] that made up the masquerade costume.

A tunic made out of dyed strips of country cloth and covered in three layers of black dyed raffia. It is accessioned as part of the costume worn by the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. The tunic was accessioned along with the mask [BM:Af.1901.722.10.a] and leggings [BM:Af.1901.722.10.c and d - now lost] that made up the masquerade costume.

An unusual cap made from coiled basketry, with a red stripes, visible on the inside. The outside of the cap is covered in flat semi-circles of wood, with toothed edges, forming ridges, which resemble hair. Two wooden toggles hang from the sides.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. The central section has two faces carved into the wood; each end is flat, with the bottom part spear shaped.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. The central section has two sets of turned wood; each end is flat, with the bottom part spear shaped.

A wooden carved gun. The British Museum records state that it is a model. Similar wooden guns are, however, often imbued with spiritual powers and used to keep dangerous devils, or debuls, in check during public performances.
A carved, wooden, female figure, with a green, yellow, and black, diamond glass set of waist beads, on a twined cord tied around the waist. She has a typical segmented neck.

This figure was described by Alldridge as a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. This example stands on an oval base and has geometric scarification marks on her lower back. She has a typical ridged hairstyle and a segmented neck. The figure is illustrated in Alldridges The Sherbro and its Hinterland, from 1901 (BMAG:WA900265).

This unusual carving depicts a male figure, standing on a pedestal. He is wearing a European top-hat, which became a symbol of prestige in the late 19th century, and a pair of boots. The pedestal has a rattle carved into it, with a circular ball, and the whole carving stands upright on a circular base.

This figure was described by Alldridge as a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. This example stands on an oval base and has geometric scarification marks on her lower back. She has a typical ridged hairstyle and a segmented neck. The figure is illustrated in Alldridges The Sherbro and its Hinterland, from 1901 (BMAG:WA900265).

This carving depicts a woman standing on a pedestal. She has a typical ridge hairstyle, with an ornate comb inserted into each side. Unusually, she is accompanied by a wooden staff, topped with a female head, resembling a sowei mask. There are many such staffs in the British Museum collection, and they are often associated with the Bundu, or Sande, society.

This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. She has a typical segmented neck, and ridged hairstyle, as well as scarification marks on her lower back. The figure wears three sets of waist beads in blue, and a beaded apron.

A possible sowei mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical five-lobed hairstyle, with geometric panels. This mask may not have been used as it does not have any holes for raffia.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This unusual example represents a reclining figure, who appears to be wearing an elaborate costume. It has a hole in its right hand, which is crossed over it front.
A spear, or javelin, made from an iron barbed point, bound to a wooden handle with leather.
A spear, or javelin, made from an iron barbed point, bound to a wooden handle with leather.
A spear, made with an iron blade, attached to a wooden shaft.
An unusual double ended spear, with an ornate, wooden shaft. One end of the spear has a pointed iron blade, whilst the other has a circular blade, with two horn-like protrusions.
A spear with an iron pointed blade. The spear shaft has been bound in bands of fur, and red and beige leather. It has a cloth and hide spear sheath.
A spear with an iron pointed blade. The spear shaft has been bound in bands of fur, and red and beige leather. It has a cloth and hide spear sheath.
A pronged weapon, used against soldiers on horses. It is made of two pointed iron prongs attached to a wooden shaft with gummed string.

An iron dagger, with one large blade, and two smaller ones on either side. The handle is wrapped in raw hide and twisted fibre. This may be a Leopard Society dagger; similar devices have been thought to have been used by members of the so-called Human Leopards, or Leopard society, as a means of blaming the deaths of their victims on leopards.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A powder horn, likely for storing gun powder. The horn has been wrapped in tooled leather, decorated with nine raised ridges. It also has a carrying strap, with leather tassels attached to it. This type of decoration is commonly known as Mandingo. Mandingo, here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: One of three Mandingo leatherwork tassels, decorated with panels of woven grass in red, black and beige. Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: One of three Mandingo leatherwork tassels, decorated with panels of woven grass in red, black and beige. Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example appears to be missing its lower half, and represents a figure, holding on to two stands protruding from its chin.

A Bambada, meaning crocodile mouth, hat, from the north of Sierra Leone, used by peoples such as the Limba or Kuranko. It is made from brown-dyed country cloth with attached leather amulets, or sebe/ sebbeh, and leather tassels. (It is likely to have accompanied the Ronko Shirt from the British Museum, accession number Af.1904.415.20)
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: A ronko, or medicine, shirt, from the north of Sierra Leone, collected in the 1890s. Ronko shirts, or gowns, are made of strips of country cloth, typically dyed a rusty reddish brown using local pigments. In the past such pigments were seen as having spiritual protective powers. This example has a number of small leather rectangles, or amulets, sewn onto it, along with leather tassels, a piece of horn, and a coiled basketry rosette. Such shirts were worn by hunters and others engaged in dangerous pursuits - this example is described as a war-shirt. Ronko shirts are also associated with the kamajors, or local militias, that fought during the recent civil war.
CulturalObject.Materials: Textile; Bone, ivory, tooth; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A rattle, made from a circle of gourd, with a rounded wickerwork basket attached to it, with a looped handle. Small stones inside the basket rattle when it is shaken.
A rattle, made from a circle of gourd, with a rounded wickerwork basket attached to it, with a looped handle. Small stones inside the basket rattle when it is shaken.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. On the top of the staff is a carved female figure with a typical segmented neck, and a ridged hairstyle.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. On the top of the staff is a carved female head with a typical segmented neck, and a ridged hairstyle.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. On the top of the staff is a carved female head with a typical segmented neck, and a ridged hairstyle.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. On the top of the staff is a carved female head with a typical segmented neck, and a ridged hairstyle.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. On the top of the staff is a carved female head with a typical segmented neck, and a ridged hairstyle.
This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff, held by high status individuals. This example has a female head carved at one end, resembling a sowei mask with a segmented neck.
A spear, with an iron blade and a carved wooden handle.

This is an example for an unusual type of bow-and-bridge harp lute, found along the coast of Sierra Leone. The sound box is carved from wood, rather than a calabash, and has a projecting figurehead, as well as hide strings. The earliest examples were collected in the 1790s and are among the earliest collected wooden artefacts from sub-Saharan Africa. The sound box resembles a boat and may have been influenced by the appearance of sailing ships.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Wood; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.
A glass bead, made from a rod of black, red and white glass. It has been cut at either end to reveal a zigzag design.
One of three glass beads. Each is made from black glass, decorated with a gold stripe, and a band of pink flowers with green leaves.
One of three glass beads. Each is made from black glass, decorated with a gold stripe, and a band of pink flowers with green leaves.
One of three glass beads. Each is made from black glass, decorated with a gold stripe, and a band of pink flowers with green leaves.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is seated, and holds a bowl.

Part of a stone figure, resembling a Nomoli, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of Nomoli figures is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they Predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is unusual, and depicts part of a seated human figure.

A Steatite, or soapstone, figure, depicting part of a female torso, with circular scarification lines around the navel. This figure may be associated to Nomoli figures, also made out of steatite. The age of nomolis relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a human head, with typical bulbous eyes, and a wide nose.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: W. R. Boddy; A. W. Boddy

The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a pointed human head, with typical bulbous eyes, and a wide nose.

They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. This example depicts a human head with plaited hair, as well as typical bulbous eyes, and a wide nose.

They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. This example depicts a human figure, standing upright.

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is heavily worn, and depicts a human figure with its arms linked.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: W. R. Boddy; A. W. Boddy

CulturalObject.Description: A cylindrical leather pouch for holding bottles. The bottom end is decorated with tooled and painted leather, and the bag is closed by drawing together the top with a braided leather strap. This bag was donated to the British Museum by Sir Harry Johnston who worked in Liberia - it may be either from Liberia or Sierra Leone. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.

Hourglass-shaped drums of this type have been called a hutamba drum in Limba, or a tamban in Yalunka. Such drums are usually beaten with a curved, or L-shaped, stick. Animal skin has been stretched over each end, and kept taught with fibre tension cords. The centre of the drum is decorated with blue zigzag lines, and orange dots.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

The British Museum catalogue records this as turtle medicine, used for casting spells. It is made from tortoise shell, wrapped in cotton cloth. Six metal chains are attached to it, each holding three cotton-wrapped bundles.
This hammer is said to have been used in conjunction with another object (accession number Af1908,0618.1), to cast spells. The end of the hammer is made of iron, and wrapped in cloth.

These items are thought to be associated with the turtle medicine, accession number BM:Af.1908.618.1, and contained within the medicine bag, accession number BM:Af.1908.618.8. This records refers to one of the two seeds.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Government of Sierra Leone; L. Page

CulturalObject.Description: An amulet, or charm, consisting of an oblong object wrapped in cotton. Two twisted iron prongs extend out of one end, adorned with red, white, and blue, twisted cords.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Government of Sierra Leone; L. Page

CulturalObject.Description: This bag is thought to have contained the turtle medicine, accession number BM:Af.1908.618.1. It is made of fur and leather, with braided leather straps sewn on the top and bottom of the bag. Parts of the strap have been decorated with woven grass.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This entry refers to a protective amulet made of organic fibre, herbs, snail shells, cotton thread, and animal fat, contained in the pocket of a ronko shirt, accession number BM:Af.1908.1013.1.a.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: G. B. Haddon Smith; W. D. Bowden

CulturalObject.Description: A ronko, or medicine, shirt, from the north of Sierra Leone. Ronko shirts, or gowns, are made of strips of country cloth, typically dyed a rusty reddish brown using local pigments. In the past such pigments were seen as having spiritual protective powers. This example has three protective amulets, likely to contain scripts from the Quran, wrapped in cotton. It also has a large pocket sewn on the inside containing a protective amulet, wrapped in organic fibre. Such shirts were worn by hunters and others engaged in dangerous pursuits - this example is described as a war-shirt. Ronko shirts are also associated with the kamajors, or local militias, that fought during the recent civil war.
CulturalObject.Materials: Textile; Bone, ivory, tooth; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: G. B. Haddon Smith; W. D. Bowden

CulturalObject.Description: A glass bottle, encased in red leatherwork and woven fibre, and with a leather covered stopper. This style of woven and tooled leatherwork resembles so-called Mandingo leatherwork, predominating among Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Glass; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A cylindrical leather pouch for holding bottles. The bottom end is decorated with tooled and painted leather, and the bag is closed by drawing together the top with a braided leather strap. The strap is decorated with elaborate embossed leatherwork, and is typical of Mandingo leatherwork. Mandingo leatherwork is associated with Muslim elites.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a seated figure, with an elongated head.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a standing female figure, on a circular base. The base has a hole bored through its middle.

A carved, steatite head, with a hole bored into the top. This carving is particularly interesting because its form resembles that of the Temne aRong aThoma mask. A related stone carving can be found in the Sierra Leone National Museum (SLNM.1964.43.01), which was collected in Tonkolili District, an area associated with the aRong aThoma masquerade tradition.

This is recorded as a divination bowl and a piece of medicine mans equipment. It is made from a calabash, of gourd, shell, and the inside has been lined with cotton. The outside of the bowl is adorned by a strip of cloth, adorned with two rows of cowrie shells. A piece of string has been attached to the cloth, to which are attached metal bells, small glass bottles containing herbs and string-bound charms, or amulets.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Metal; Glass; Shell; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: This is labelled in the British Museum catalogue as a divination switch. It consists of a bundle of cane sticks, bound with cotton and cowrie shells at one end. Similar items have been associated with the Arieogbo, or Ayogbo, society, used for making accusations of witchcraft.

An unusual woven raffia, or basketry, conical cap, or hat. The outside is covered in raffia bristles, layered in dark and light brown stripes. It is adorned with strips of leather, fastened with leather-covered buttons.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a human head, and may have originally been attached to a body, now missing.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This unusual example depicts a figure, riding a tusked elephant.

A female figure, carved of wood. She is standing upright, with her hands resting underneath her breasts. She has a particular hairstyle with ridges running from the front of her head, to the back, terminating in two points. As with two other examples from the British Museums collections, this ridge is accompanied by two large disc ears, and wide hips (see BM:Af.1954.23.3664. and BM:Af.1925.-.17.). This example also has a geometric incised band around her stomach, and wears earrings made of red glass beads, a series of necklaces in black, blue, green, and red, beads, a sash and yellow, and green. glass waist beads. As with the other examples, she is wearing ankle boots.

A double bladed sword. It has a flat iron blade that splits off down to middle, forming two points curving outwards. The blade is decorated with a row of circles down the centre, and is attached to a wooden hilt.
A bangle, made from elephant pad.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A leather whip. The handle is made of wood, and covered with three stripes on tooled leather; one buff, and two darn brown. The whip itself is made of plaited leather.
A sling, made out of woven palm fibre,
A carved, wooden, female figure, standing on a circular base. Her hands are resting at her waist, and she has a ridged hairstyle.

A carved, wooden, female figure. Her hands are resting on her hips, and she has a long, segmented, neck, along with five hair ridges. She has holes bored through each of her legs, suggesting she may have been carved to be attached to something else.
A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is carved of wood, with a crown-shaped metal knob on the end.
An iron spear. It is flat and squared at one end and pointed, with ridge running down middle, at the opposite end. The centre of spear is etched with a geometric design.
A small iron finger ring, made from a length of twisted iron, bent into a circle.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid bands of ivory, wood, brass and metal. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid bands of ivory, wood, brass and metal. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.
Three oblong orange carnelian beads.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a human head, with a large hole bored into the top.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a human head, without a neck.
A carved wooden comb. It has seven teeth, extending from an elaborate handle, decorated with carved flowers, a hollowed x shape and a spoked wheel.
A carved wooden comb. It has seven teeth, extending from an elaborate handle, with a carved female figure standing on a base with geometric patterns.

This bundle of thirty cane sticks, bound with red cotton, is recorded in the British Museum catalogue as being associated with the Wunde society. The Wunde society is an exclusive male society among the Kpa Mende. The collector, John de Hart, wrote an article called The Wunde Society Dance in Sierra Leone Studies, 1920.

This is a headdress worn by members of the mens Wunde society, when is was collected in the early 20th century. It has a typical basket dome, which is then covered in cloth and painted with blue and red triangles. The top of the dome is mounted by a large tuft of feathers, and a tail of feathers, tied with string, is attached to the dome along with a string of coral beads.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: This axe is described in the British Museum catalogue as a medicine bag, but may also be referred to as an amulet or charm. It consists of a leather cylindrical bag that has been filled with magical substances, or herbs, and fastened with leather straps and metal rings.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre; Metal

CulturalObject.Description: An Amulet, or charm, made of a bundle wrapped in cloth and natural fibre string. It is adorned with cowrie shells and cornelian beads.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Metal; Shell; Stone; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: The British Museum catalogue records this as a charm, though it is unknown whether tit had and spiritual power. It is made out of banana skin.
The British Museum catalogue records this as a charm. It consists of a cowrie shell tied with a piece of fibre string.
A polished stone axe head.
A polished stone axe head fragment.
This is recorded as a possible stone chisel in the British Museum catalogue; it may also be a small axe.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a seated male, holding onto his beard with two hands.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a woman with a neck ring, and ridged hairstyle.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a woman with a neck ring, and ridged hairstyle. The figure has scarification on the stomach, and lower back.
A wooden staff, surmounted by a full human figure, with a square head.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, with a cylindrical base.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts two, connected, faces, looking in opposite directions. Each head appears to be wearing a rimmed cap.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

An iron dagger, with one large blade, and two smaller ones on either side. The handle is made from a looped piece of iron. This may be a Leopard Society dagger; similar devices have been thought to have been used by members of the so-called Human Leopards, or Leopard society, as a means of blaming the deaths of their victims on leopards.

This item is recorded in the British Museum catalogue as a leopard society medicine bag. It is made from woven cotton with braided cord loops to tie it shut. There is a metal padlock attached to the cord.

This item is recorded in the British Museum catalogue as a leopard society medicine bag. It is made from woven cotton with braided cord loops to tie it shut. There is a metal padlock attached to the cord.
The British Museum catalogue records this as a charm. It consists of a section of horn, tied to a loop of cotton cord.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: The British Museum catalogue records this as a charm. It consists of a rectangular box, covered in cotton and tied with braided skin. Rectangles, like this one, often contain Quranic texts.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, with a square pedestal baring a chequered design. The pedestal has been hollowed out, to contain seed counters.

A set of 21 dried beans, used for playing Warri. Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise.

This unusual item is an axe-shaped piece of steatite, or soapstone, which has three figures carved into it. Is resembles another example in the British Museum collection from Sierra Leone, accession number BM:Af.1972.25.1.

A female figure, carved of wood. She is standing upright, with her hands resting on her waist. She has a particular hairstyle with ridges running from the front of her head, to the back, terminating in a point. As with two other examples from the British Museums collections, this ridge is accompanied by two large disc ears, and wide hips (see BM:Af.1954.23.3664. and BM:Af.1911-225). This example also has a geometric incised rectangle on her stomach, and a grey glass beaded necklace.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: E. W. Liddell; J. Sinclair Liddell

CulturalObject.Description: This is a very unusual item, being one of the only examples of a wooden carving from Sierra Leone, that resembles the ancient Nomoli steatite figures from the south-east. It is thought to be of the similar age. It has a detachable head, and sits in a kneeling position. This item came from the 1924 Sierra Leone exhibition in Wembley, London, put together by a number of commissioners, one of which was E. F. Sayers. E. F. Sayers had described an ancient wooden statuette, bearing a marked resemblance to this figure, in a cave near Kakoia, a Limba town in the north of Sierra Leone. It is possible, therefore, that this item is the figure from Kakoia.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. It is composed of eight strips of weft faced plain weave with undyed cotton warps, and broad bands of black, yellow and natural coloured cotton. It has a central band, composed of slim stripes of undyed, red, black and yellow, all of which are part of the ground weave. The colours of this cloth are unusual for Sierra Leone, but since it came from the Sierra Leone Exhibition Commissioners at the 1924 British Empire Exhibition, its Sierra Leone credentials are impeccable.

A Mandingo, or Kusaibi, gown, exhibited at the 1924 British Empire Exhibition at Wembley, in London. It is made from fourteen narrow strips of indigo dyed cotton, and extensively embroidered in cotton and wool, in white, blue, red, and pink. The cream geometric embroidery on the front of the gown, composing of three interlinked squares, is thought to represent a compound of houses. The term Mandingo here, is associated with Muslim elites from the north of Sierra Leone.

This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a typical elongated, segmented, neck, and scarification marks on her stomach and lower back.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: E. W. Liddell; J. Sinclair Liddell

CulturalObject.Description: This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a typical elongated, segmented, neck, and ridged hairstyle. She has scarification marks running down her back, on her breasts, and hips.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a seated figure, resting its hands underneath its chin.
An amulet, or charm, made from a section of animal horn, which the wider end wrapped in skin. The British Museum catalogue notes it comes from the leopard society.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A clay or mud container, decorated with metal, cowrie shells, and red beads. The British Museum catalogue notes that it was used to contain medicine by the Leopard society.
CulturalObject.Materials: Ceramic; Vegetable, organic fibre; Shell; Glass; Metal; Stone; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: An amulet, or charm, consisting of an oblong block of wood, with a rectangular cloth bundle nailed in the middle of it. The British Museum catalogue records this as Leopard society medicine.

This item is recorded in the British Museum catalogue as a leopard society medicine bag. It is made from woven cotton with braided cord loops to tie it shut. There is a metal padlock attached to the cord.

This axe is described in the British Museum catalogue as belonging to the Leopard Society. It has a wooden handle, which is attached a flat metal blade. The blade has five curved metal spikes protruding from it; two from the top, and three from the bottom. It has a twisted fibre loop attached to the bottom of the handle. Items like this were used by the Human Leopards, to blame the deaths of their victims on wild animals.
A pair of iron pincers. The British Museum catalogue describes these as Leopard society pincers.
A hammer, made from a metal head, attached to a carved wooden handle. The British Museum catalogue describes this as a Leopard society hammer.

This amulet, or charm, is made from a piece of horn that has been covered in red leather. It has a central panel of woven grass in beige and dark red. The British Museum catalogue records this as Leopard society medicine.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: An amulet, or charm, consisting of a large snail shell, containing a medicine made of organic material. It is sealed with four cowrie shells and a circular metal disc, possibly a coin. The British Museum catalogue records this as Leopard society medicine.

A composite amulet, or charm, consisting of an oblong object, bound in an organic substance and adorned with cowrie shells and small white glass beads. A piece of copper is embedded in the top. The British Museum catalogue records this as Leopard society medicine.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a female figure, bent at the waist and supported by the hands and feet.
A pipe for smoking tobacco, made out of iron. It has a thin tube, and a cylindrical bowl with an x carved on the side. A twisted fibre cord is tied to the stem.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example is composed of ten strips of undyed cotton warps, with cream, and indigo-dyed, warps. Sewn together they create seven bands of geometric patterning; the central band consists of a diamond based pattern produced using supplementary weft in natural cotton over a blue background.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example consists of eight strips, with blocks of dark blue, light blue, yellow, green, buff, and undyed, weft. Sewn together, they create six central strips, decorated in geometric bands. The central section of the cloth has representations of two houses, suggesting the cloth may have been made to hang, and be viewed horizontally.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of Njawi-Kpokpo cloth, used fro formal or ceremonial purposes, such as the coming out of girls, initiated into the Sande society, or more recently, in political ceremonies. This example is composed of eleven strips of undyed, woven, cotton, embroidered with indigo dyed string. There is a central box motif, called a tenoi in Mende, with four diagonals going out to the four corners.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of a kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth hammock, used for carrying chiefs. Hammocks, like this one, would usually be accompanied by a canopy borne on the heads of the carriers that shielded the chief from the sun. This is a particularly fine example.

This cotton cloth is made from a single piece of cotton, rather than sewing together numerous strips. Looms that made cloth of this width were very rare in Sierra Leone before 1934, when it entered the museum, suggesting it may not be Sierra Leonean (the providence of the cloth is Africa). It is composed of stripes of weft faced, plain weave, consisting of natural cotton coloured warps and blue, orange, and yellow, dyed cotton, and natural coloured cotton, wefts.

This gown is composed of seven strips of country cloth, sewn together to create intricate geometric patterns in indigo, pink and cream. Country cloth is traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. The patch-work effect created here, by bringing together a number of contrasting patterns, resembles some kpokpo cloths at the turn of the 20th century. It is thought to be Mende, Sherbro of Vai.

A Mandingo gown, made from 66 narrow strips of un-dyed, plain weave, cotton. It is elaborately embroidered in herringbone and straight stitch, forming typical geometric and, less common, figurative designs. The compositions of three and four squares on the front and back, are thought to represent a compound. The term Mandingo here, is associated with Muslim elites from the north of Sierra Leone.

A gown, made from two wide strips of, likely imported, machine woven cotton. The cloth has been tie, and stitch, dyed, with indigo. Stitch dying is more prominent on the top half, and resembles methods of dying for making garra cloth.
This is a scraper, or an axe, made out of chipped hard stone.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
A stone core, left after working on a larger piece of stone, and systematically chipping off smaller tools, such as blades and scrapers.
A scraper, made from a piece of had stone. A series of small flakes have been removed from two sides to create sharp edges.
A point, made from a piece of flaked hard stone. It is shaped into a projectile point by chipping two main facets, and a series of smaller chips from two sides, to create a cutting point.
A point, made from a piece of flaked quartz. It is shaped into a projectile point by chipping two main facets, and a series of smaller chips from two sides, to create a cutting point.
A point, made from a piece of flaked quartz. It is shaped into a projectile point by chipping two main facets, and a series of smaller chips from two sides, to create a cutting point.
A point, made from a piece of flaked quartz. It is shaped into a projectile point by chipping two main facets, and a series of smaller chips from two sides, to create a cutting point.
A scraper, or blade, made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from two sides to create sharp edges.
A scraper, or blade, made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from two sides to create sharp edges.
This is a scraper, or an axe, made out of chipped hard stone.
A scraper made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from two sides to create sharp edges.
A small blade, made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from the longitudinal side, to create a sharp edge.
A scraper made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from two sides to create sharp edges.
A small blade, made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from the longitudinal side, to create a sharp edge.
A celt, or chisel, made out of chipped hard stone.

CulturalObject.Description: A point, made from a piece of flaked quartz. It is shaped into a projectile point by chipping two main facets, and a series of smaller chips from two sides, to create a cutting point.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: J. D. Pollett; Norman Ross Junner

CulturalObject.Description: A point, made from a piece of flaked quartz. It is shaped into a projectile point by chipping two main facets, and a series of smaller chips from two sides, to create a cutting point.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: J. D. Pollett; Norman Ross Junner

CulturalObject.Description: A small blade, or point, made from a piece of quartz. A series of small flakes have been removed from the longitudinal side, to create a sharp edge.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: J. D. Pollett; Norman Ross Junner

CulturalObject.Description: This is an axe, made out of chipped hard stone.
A celt, or chisel, made out of chipped hard stone.
A celt, or chisel, made out of chipped hard stone.
A celt, or chisel, made out of chipped hard stone.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, and has a female head with neck rings protruding from one end. The pedestal has been hollowed out, for storing counters,

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, and has two round posts on the bottom for support.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a kneeling figure, with an elongated head.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
This is an axe, made out of chipped and polished hard stone.

This is a portable loom, used for weaving country cloth; a piece of half woven cloth can be seen in the loom. It is made of wood and cane, and came with a beater and two heddles with a spool of white cotton.
A cane spool of spun, green, cotton thread.
A wooden spool, carved to a point at each end. It is holding a length of beige spun cotton thread.
A wooden spool, carved to a point at each end. It is holding a length of beige spun cotton thread.

A wooden spool, carved to a point at each end. It is holding a length of blue spun cotton thread.
A wooden spool, carved to a point at each end. It is holding a length of green spun cotton thread.

This is a shuttle, which stores the weft yarn (in this case cotton thread) as it is passed back and forth, through the shed. This example is in the shape of a boat, with designs carved on the bow and stern.
A wooden spool, holding a length of spun, undyed, cotton thread. It is contained within a shuttle, shaped like a boat (accession number BM:Af.1937.607.2.a.)
A sample of spun cotton thread, dyed green.

A hand-woven piece of cloth, composing of a single strip made of natural cotton warps (the vertical strands), and light and dark blue dyed cotton wefts (the horizontal weave). It is fringed with twisted warps at either end. The pattern consists of alternating light blue and dark blue horizontal stripes.

A wooden spool, holding a length of spun, undyed, cotton thread. It is contained within a shuttle, shaped like a boat (accession number BM:Af.1937.607.3.a.).
