Banda masks are more commonly associated with the Baga, Lauma and Nalu groups in Guinea, but have also been known to be used by Soso [Susu] people. This example was apparently collected in a pair [with BM:Af.1938.216.2] on Tasso Island, in the Sierra Leone River, and was probably part of a masking performance put together for visitors when it was collected in the 1930s. In Guinea, Banda, or Landa, masks are part of the circumcision ceremony for young boys and commonly depict a mixture of crocodile and human features. The masks are generally worn flat on the head, or sloping forward at an angle, over the face.

Banda masks are more commonly associated with the Baga, Lauma and Nalu groups in Guinea, but have also been known to be used by Soso [Susu] people. This example was apparently collected in a pair on Tasso Island, in the Western area of Sierra Leone, and was probably part of a masking performance put together for visitors when it was collected in the 1930s. In Guinea, Banda, or Landa, masks are part of the circumcision ceremony for young boys and commonly depict a mixture of crocodile and human features. The masks are generally worn flat on the head, or sloping forward at an angle, over the face. This example does not quite fit the description of a typical Banda Mask as it is relatively plain.

A bowl-shaped drum, commonly know as a bote. It has a wooden circular base, with hide stretched over the top, held in place by hide thongs. The bote has two handles. Bote drums are commonly associated with Susu musicians, though are found across Sierra Leone. This example is described in the British Museum records, as a circumcision drum
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A wooden carving of a male snake charmer. He wears a headdress and a stiff leather girdle and neckpiece, called kololewengoi in Mende, and is holding a snake in either hand. This figure is likely to have been carved as a representation of a snake charmer, or dancer, rather than for any ritual significance. It is one of a number of similar figures, that seem to have been carved by the same carver or in the same workshop. The name of the carver is thought to be Sogande, who was active in the 1930s.

A bolon, or bolon bata, is commonly known as a Fula instrument; it resembles a harp lute. This example consists of a calabash resonator, a wooden neck with fibre strings, and a wire resonators at the base. The calabash is half covered in animal hide, likely to be goat hide.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin; Metal

CulturalObject.Description: Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has finely carved naturalistic hair braids, drawn up into top knots, and is unusually thin. The carver of this mask has been identified as Boni of Kopama in Bonthe district.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Glendining and Co; R. S. Rattray

CulturalObject.Description: Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a container adorning her hairstyle and a small amulet, or sebe/ sebbeh, woven into the front. The mask is complete with its black raffia.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Glendining and Co; R. S. Rattray

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a seated male figure, perched on a stool. He has a hole in his chest, and entered the collection with a similar female figure, BM:Af.1938.1014.2.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a kneeling female figure, holding a cylindrical object. She has a hole in her head, and entered the collection with a similar male figure, BM:Af.1938.1014.1.

This is a musical horn, made out of ivory. It has a side-blown mouth piece and a dark brown patina. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief.

This represents a stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is, however, unusual, as it represents a bent over, toothed, animal. The British Museum collection has another, similar, example, see BM:Af.1939.27.2.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of nine strips of plain weave, striped in brown, green, and yellow. It has been hand-hemmed. The British Museum catalogue notes this pattern is known as kulu nyei, and that the cloth was worn by women.
An unidentified circular object made of metal metal covered with skin with band of decorated plaited fibre around the circumference.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin;Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A glass bottle, encased in red leatherwork and woven red and beige fibre, and with a woven stopper. This style of woven and tooled leatherwork resembles so-called Mandingo leatherwork, predominating among Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Glass; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A European glass bottle, encased in red leatherwork and woven red, black, and beige, fibre. It has two tassels attached to the neck, and a painted decoration on the base. This style of woven and tooled leatherwork resembles so-called Mandingo leatherwork, predominating among Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Glass; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A European blue glass bottle, encased in red, blue, and white, beadwork. It has a stopper which is also covered in beadwork, as well as a line of tassels, ending with cowrie sells. An orange bead is sewn onto the end of the stopper, which is inserted into the bottle.

A circular, leather covered object, with a hole through the middle. It is decorated in so-called Mandingo leatherwork, including a band of woven grass. It is likely to be a toggle from a larger leather object, such as a bag.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin;Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is wearing a European style crown and a state umbrella, similar to that used by the Asante King Prempeh, when he was exiled to Sierra Leone in the early years of the 20th century.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example wears an elaborate headdress with three panels, of what resembles woven basketwork, and two circular plates framing either side of the face. The top of the mask is surmounted by four birds.

A nyayaru , or chordophone, known colloquially as a Fula violin. It is composed of a gourd resonator and dark hair stretched over a bridge and up the wooden neck. The gourd resonator is covered in scaled reptile skin, probably snake, and secured by cane pins. Is it played with a bow made from an arched split cane, with animal hair, bounded at the ends with twisted fibre.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A Bambada, meaning crocodile mouth, hat, from the north of Sierra Leone, used by peoples such as the Limba or Kuranko. This example is made from brown cloth, which has been embroidered with a geometric design, in white, black, yellow and red cotton.

A Bambada, meaning crocodile mouth, hat, from the north of Sierra Leone, used by peoples such as the Limba or Kuranko. This example is made from brown cloth, which has been embroidered with a geometric design, in white, black, green, blue, yellow, and red, cotton.

A caryatid carved wooden stool. Caryatid refers to a platform, supported by figures. This example is supported by two male figures, and two female figures. Three of the figures wear waist bands, two made out of plaited fibre string, and one with black glass beads. Though the provenance of this stool is attributed to Mali, Nigeria or Sierra Leone, the style is similar to caryatid Sapi-Portuguese salt cellars, suggesting it is likely to be Sierra Leonean.

The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example shows a figure, sitting crossed legged.

CulturalObject.Description: Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped and the pedestal has a carved geometric pattern.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Irene M. Beasley; Blackmore Museum, Salisbury; Harry G. Beasley

A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

CulturalObject.Description: This is a musical horn, made out of ivory. It has a side-blown mouth piece and is decorated with a carved snake, swallowing a frog. It is described as a Kissi, or Kisi, horn, from the Sierra Leone-Guinea-Liberia border. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief.

A carved female bust, that looks like it has been sawn off the base, indicating that it might have originated as a full figure. She has a typical segmented neck, and rows of cowrie shells running around the head, and from front to back. The top of the head is surmounted by a coiled object, which may represent an amulet, or charm.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a seated male, with bulbous eyes, and a broad nose. He is wearing a fringed collar, or necklet of animal teeth.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts two figures standing back-to-back. Each figure rests its hands on a globular object at its front, which may also be a protruding stomach.

This example depicts a single human figure, with its hands resting at the front on a protruding stomach.

This example is relatively unclear, and represents a standing figure, with a ridged hairstyle.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. This figure has a broad nose and an un-detailed, rounded, body.

This is a wooden staff, carved with an oblong rattle in its shaft. Protruding from the rattle is a segmented section, ending in a representation of a sowei mask. Staffs, like this one, have been a associated with the Sande, or Bundu, society.
A stone adze, or celt, used for smoothing rough-cut wood. It is made from polished, fine-grained stone, and has a convex top.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical five-lobed hairstyle, with a carved relief comb on the left side, and a small piece of bone tied to the back. She is complete with raffia, attached through drilled holes along the base.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example wears a diamond shaped locket, bracelets, armbands and a belt.
A carved, wooden, female figure. She has a diamond shaped face and a segmented neck.
A carved wooden baton, surmounted by a human head, with a ridged hairstyle and segmented neck. The bottom of the baton has a number of figures burnt into the surface, including snakes and fish.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This figure is kneeling, and holds its hands up towards its head.

This example represents a human head with enlarge facial features.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. It has two holes bored in between its legs.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields.
