The features of this example are indistinct; British Museum records note that it may be unfinished.
A leather charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It has been made out of a piece of brown leather, sewn into a tube. The ends have been bound in white leather.
An amulet, or charm, wrapped in cloth and tied onto a twists fibre string.
A polished stone axe-head. The top is damaged.
A whetstone, made of a grey-green hard stone. It has iron traces on two sides, suggesting it was used to sharpen iron implements.
Eight carnelian beads. Six are oblong, one is rounded and one is squared.

A carved, wooden, likely representation of a Tongo Player; the Tongo Players were witch finders in southern Sierra Leone in the late 19th and early 20th century. They wore a girdle of stiff leather flaps, called kololewengoi, as this figure does. The figure holds what looks like a rattle in front of him, and has been painted in red, white, and brown, paint. This carving is similar to another in the British Museum collection, accession number Af1938,0216.5, and was probably also carved as a representation rather than a ritual object.
A point, made from a piece of hard stone.
A point, made from a piece of hard stone.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.
A blade, made from a piece of stone. A series of small flakes have been removed from the longitudinal side, to create a sharp edge.

This is recorded as Sowei Mask: a wooden helmet mask, used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. This example is, however, unusual, and might, rather, have been carved for sale.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of 13 strips of plain weave, striped with undyed, and indigo dyed, cotton. The piece of cloth is un-hemmed.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of 13 strips of plain weave, striped with undyed, and indigo dyed, cotton. The piece of cloth is un-hemmed.

This cotton cloth is made from a single piece, measuring 87cm in width, rather than sewing together numerous strips. Looms that made cloth of this width were very rare in Sierra Leone before 1949, when it entered the museum, suggesting it may not be Sierra Leonean. It is striped in undyed, and indigo-dyed, cotton.

This is a 16th century ivory saltcellar or box. The conical base depicts three female figures, alternating with crocodiles. One the figures looks like it is positioned in front of a crucifix. A snake can be seen spiralling up towards the bowl. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents an animal-like male figure, with bared teeth.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a squatting figure, holding a globular object with holes bored into it. It is missing its head.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a seated figure, with long, raised, legs, bent at the knee.

A Mandingo gown, made from 43 narrow strips of indigo, plain weave, cotton. It is embroidered with cotton over the front and back in white, yellow, green, blue, and red. The predominant shapes are crosses, diamonds, zigzags, stripes, and spirals. It has a pocket just below the neckline on the front. The term Mandingo here, is associated with Muslim elites from the north of Sierra Leone.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is damaged at the back, and represents a kneeling figure.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a kneeling figure.
A circular mat, made from woven and coiled cane and raffia, or grass. It has a geometric, circular, design in red and black.
A circular mat, made from woven and coiled cane and raffia, or grass. It has a geometric, circular, design in red and black.

A wooden staff, with a female head at one end. The head resembles a sowei mask, with its ridged hairstyle and segmented neck. The British Museum catalogue suggests it might be associated with the Sande society.

A brush, or broom, for sweeping the floor. It is made out of palm fibres which have been folded in half, and reinforced with cane. Its handle has a geometric design in dark and light fibres. The British Museum catalogue described the brush as a fan.

A brush, or broom, for sweeping the floor. It is made out of palm fibres which have been folded in half, and reinforced with cane. Its handle has a geometric design. The British Museum catalogue described the brush as a fan.
A pair of bangles made out of elephant pad. The British Museum catalogue notes that these were worn by a chief.
A wooden fetter, or binding, made from a carved piece of wood. A small piece of wood is inserted through a hole in either side of the rectangle.

This is a musical horn, made out of ivory. It has a side-blown mouth piece, decorated with geometric designs in relief. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example wears a large sebe/sebbeh, or amulet, as ornament and protection, and has its black-dyed raffia attached.
This is a large axe, made out of chipped hard stone.
A celt, or chisel, made out of chipped hard stone.
A celt, or chisel, made out of chipped, and polished, hard stone.
A hammer stone, consisting of a globular piece of rock, with a hole bored into the middle.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example has an elaborate base, which has been hollowed out, leaving strands of twined wood in an x shape. Two carved birds sit inside the base, along with a pull-out draw for storing counters. It comes with a peg, used for locking the various components of the board together.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example has an elaborate base, which has been hollowed out, leaving strands of twined wood in an x shape. Two carved birds sit inside the base, along with a pull-out draw for storing counters. It comes with a peg, used for locking the various components of the board together.

This is a wooden draw, used for storing counters for playing Warri. Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. Counters are usually made out of seeds or dried beans, but have also been known to be bullets. Warri is thought to have been originally played by warriors to relax after fighting battles as other forms of entertainment, such as dancing, would make too much noise and might give them away. The draw comes inserted into a very elaborate Warri board from the British Museum, its number is 1950 15 1 1a.

This high cap is made from six pieces of un-dyed cotton, with an indigo blue design woven into the weft. The body of the cap has a central band with a diamond design, and is bordered with zigzag embroidery; whilst the top is composed of five pieces of cotton with a zigzag weft along the seams. Is was acquired by Inspector Bannerman-Phillips from Chief Santigui Mahdi, who is thought to have been a Temne chief along the southern Temne-Mende border in 1888.
A wooden fetter, or binding, made from a carved piece of wood. A small piece of wood is inserted through a hole in either side of the rectangle.
A carved wooden baton. It is decorated with geometric patterning carved in the centre, and there is a knob at top of handle, carved with a hole, through which is threaded a leather loop.

A Malian tilbi gown made from unbleached calico, or unprocessed cotton, with a crotchet design. The design has been made by removing areas of calico, and replacing them with cream crotchet work, arranged in geometric patterns. There are also areas of embroidery in pink and blue dyed cotton. Tilbi gowns of this sort were worn by elites in the Niger trading towns of Djenne and Timbuktu, in what is now Mali. This example is interesting as, though it was made in Mali, it was collected in Sierra Leone by Inspector Bannerman-Phillips. Records from the time state that it was taken from Temne Chief Santigui Mahdi, during military operations against the Yonne Temne in 1888.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals, missing the top strap. They have thick layered leather soles. Originally, they also bore a leather strap with a button covered in woven grass, and came with a bag. Mandingo was a term often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals, missing the top strap. They have thick layered leather soles. Originally, they also bore a leather strap with a button covered in woven grass, and came with a bag. Mandingo was a term often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.

A sword, with a double edged iron blade. Three lines are etched down the middle of the blade on one side. 952 is etched near hilt on one side, and CHURCHOR BROTHER on other. The wooden hilt decorated by inlaid silver wire. The British Museum catalogue notes that it is from a chief. It has a leather tooled sheath, originally having a metal case.

A sword, with a double edged iron blade. Three lines are etched down the middle of the blade on one side. 952 is etched near hilt on one side, and CHURCHOR BROTHER on other. The wooden hilt decorated by inlaid silver wire. The British Museum catalogue notes that it is from a chief. It has a leather tooled sheath, originally having a metal case.

A chiefs sword with an iron blade and a carved wooden hilt, with silver-plate mounts. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with inlaid plaited grass, and a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid and bound with bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid and bound with bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Religious/ ritual equiptment; Regailia; Jewellery, body ornament
CulturalObject.Description: A leather charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consisted of a rectangular leather box, decorated with plaited leather and grass, resembling Mandingo leatherwork. A loop is attached to each corner, and it is threaded onto a strap with a metal buckle. The British Museum catalogue notes that it was worn around the neck of a chief.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A hat, made from coiled grass, or raffia. It has a wide brim, decorated with an orange and black geometric design, showing diamonds and rectangles.
A carved, wooden, female head with a ridged hairstyle, and what may be tooled leather hair pieces, accentuated by white paint. Her face appears to be stained red, and she has a segmented neck.
A carved wooden comb with nine teeth. It has an elaborate handle with a semi-circle, leading up to a small rattle and ending in a spoked circle.

This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has scarification marks on her stomach and wears a yellow and blue beaded necklace, as well as a green, blue, and white, set of waist beads.

A coiled rounded basket, with a lid. It is woven with a pattern made from light red, beige, and brown, coloured grass, or raffia. It has a carrying loop, fastened to two small bent wooden handles at either side.

A coiled rounded basket, with a lid. It is woven with a pattern made from light red, beige, and brown, coloured grass, or raffia. It has a carrying loop, fastened to two small bent wooden handles at either side.

Parts of a Mende loom for weaving strips of country cloth. It is made of wood, cane, and course organic fibres. The loom is threaded for use, and has a partially woven length of white and cream, striped cotton, measuring 270mm by 80mm.

A collection of objects in a glass-sided box, described as a composite sacred object in the British Museum catalogue. The box is divided in two; the top half contains three stones; the bottom a collection of cowrie shells, beads and white metal plates and rings.

Two charms, or amulets, made out of string and displayed in a wooden box. The 19th century original label for these items reads This dread of fangi medicine has great hold even over some Christians. A good Christian servant, who was rather unwell, has been known to go 100 miles, because he was convinced that someone was working fangi against him. The real fangi (made from dead peoples bodies) is a powerful poison.. .
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Church Missionary Society; J. W. Humphrey

CulturalObject.Description: A female figure, carved of wood. She is standing upright, and carrying a child on her back, supported by fabric held with both hands. She wears a lappa, or skirt, and has typical segmented neck.

A Kabemba, or Ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example is ovoid in shape and decorated with strips of metal. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides.

A coil weave lidded basket, commonly known as shuku blai. Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is made from red, dark brown, and undyed fibre.

A coil weave lidded basket, commonly known as shuku blai. Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is made from red, dark brown, and undyed, fibre.
A raffia coiled fan. It has a looped handle, supported by a piece of cane, and a geometric, circular, design in red, ochre, umber and beige.
A ceramic, or pottery, bowl made from clay with mica, and burnished with a pebble. It is rounded in shape, and tapers in to a raised lip.
A leather whip. The handle is covered in red and brown leather, and raw hide, and has a carrying loop. The whip thongs are made from plaited, off-white, hide.
A small container, made out of a piece of ram, or sheep, horn. A piece of leather is threaded through a hole pierced through the open end.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A comb made from seven bone teeth, bound together with string.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: Harps like this one, are commonly known as Kru (or Kroo) harps. They are made from a semi-spherical gourd resonator, to which is attached a Y-shaped piece of wood, fastened with fibre and gum, and wrapped in animal hide. Strings of fibre are lashed across the Y, inserted through holes carved in one side, and tied to the other. This example has been painted black.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. It came from the Freetown Public Relations Office in the 1950s, but it thought it may have been woven in Guinea as the pattern it unusual for Sierra Leone.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is very unusual, and has been labelled haku or tortoise back cloth. It is composed of 13 strips sewn together, to create an intricate chequerboard pattern in cream and indigo, resembling the pattern on a tortoise back.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example is composed of six strips of hand-woven cloth with combinations of cream, yellow, brown, blue, and orange, blocks and geometric shapes, including diamonds, lozenges and cheques. Sewn together they create a complex chequered effect.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of Njawi-Kpokpo cloth, used fro formal or ceremonial purposes, such as the coming out of girls, initiated into the Sande society, or more recently, in political ceremonies. This example is composed of 11 strips in natural cotton, with bands of elaborate indigo supplementary weft in geometric patterns.

A carved ivory, bowl-shaped, box. The bottom half is decorated with two panels, each containing two crocodiles in relief. The lid is topped with a male Janus head, referring to a face appearing on the front, and back. This is likely to be a Sapi-Portuguese item; a term coined by the Portuguese in the 15th century to refer to items patronised for the European market. Such items often display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form.

A carved ivory, bowl-shaped, box. The bottom half is decorated with two panels, each containing two crocodiles in relief. The lid is topped with a male Janus head, referring to a face appearing on the front, and back. This is likely to be a Sapi-Portuguese item; a term coined by the Portuguese in the 15th century to refer to items patronised for the European market. Such items often display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form.

This cylindrical quartz object, with a pointed end, is recorded in the British Museum catalogue as either a small pestle, possibly for snuff, or a plug for a bottle. It is more likely to be the latter.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have thick layered leather soles, with tooled red leather straps, held together with a large black button, bordered with plaited grass and leather. They were collected by the Church Missionary Society, and though the provenance given to them in the British Museum catalogue notes they are Nigerian Hausa, they are more likely to be Sierra Leonean. Mandingo was often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have thick layered leather soles, with tooled red leather straps, held together with a large black button, bordered with plaited grass and leather. They were collected by the Church Missionary Society, and though the provenance given to them in the British Museum catalogue notes they are Nigerian Hausa, they are more likely to be Sierra Leonean. Mandingo was often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A set of 12 arrows, with iron arrow heads, and cane shafts. The arrowheads are attached to the shafts with gummed cloth. Six have straight heads with barbed shanks, and the other six have triangular barbed heads, with twisted shanks. They are contained with in an untreated, furry, hide case, or quiver.

A set of 12 arrows, with iron arrow heads, and cane shafts. The arrowheads are attached to the shafts with gummed cloth. Six have straight heads with barbed shanks, and the other six have triangular barbed heads, with twisted shanks. They are contained with in an untreated, furry, hide case, or quiver. This entry refers to the quiver lid.

A set of 12 arrows, with iron arrow heads, and cane shafts. The arrowheads are attached to the shafts with gummed cloth. Six have straight heads with barbed shanks, and the other six have triangular barbed heads, with twisted shanks. They are contained with in an untreated, furry, hide case, or quiver.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example Has a hole in the crown of its head, and is depicted riding an elephant.

This is likely to be a kabemba, or ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. Such masks were largely collected in the first decade of the 20th century. This example has two metal-tipped horns, pointing backwards, and is decorated with cut strips of metal.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is elaborately carved into the shape of a wheelbarrow, with four, large, spoked wheels. Is it complete with cowrie shell counters.

A model canoe, carved out of wood. An intricate geometric pattern has been engraved along the base. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs

A xylophone-like musical instrument, called a balangi, or balanjii, consisting of a series of wooden tone bars or keys attached to a wooden frame with small gourd resonators underneath, played with two beaters. It is particularly associated with the Kuranko, and other ethno-linguistic groups of Mande origin, in northern Sierra Leone. This one has 15 wooden rungs and 16 gourd fruits underneath.

This is an unusual cylindrical drum, on a wooden tripod base with a carved geometric pattern. The skin membrane is stretched over and secured with natural fibre ties. A similar drum appears in one of the Alldridge photographs, where is it described as the town drum of Fabala, which lies in the north.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: Hourglass-shaped drums of this type, have been called a hutamba drum in Limba, or a tamban in Yalunka. Such drums are usually beaten with a curved, or L-shaped, stick. Animal skin has been stretched over each end, and kept taught with fibre tension cords.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A cylindrical drum, carved of wood. Skin membranes are stretched over each end, with fibre ties. One name given to such drums is dundu; it is typically beaten with a curved, or L-shaped, stick.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A bowl-shaped drum, commonly know as a bote. It has a wooden circular base, with hide stretched over the top, held in place by hide thongs. The bote has two handles. Bote drums are commonly associated with Susu musicians, though are found across Sierra Leone. This example may also be a tabulay, or thabule in Temne, used to call people to meetings, or prayers.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: An L-shaped drum stick. A twisted fibre cord is threaded through a hole in the end, to be used as a wrist strap.

This is a representation of a sowei mask, though it is likely to have been made for sale, rather than for use. It shows no signs of use and is too narrow to be worn. It is carved in a style that has been attributed to Gola people on the Sierra Leone-Liberia border; there are many examples of these masks in European museums. This mask has a singular lobed hairstyle and is undyed.
A necklace made from three rows of cowrie shells.
A dagger with an unusual, curved, iron blade topped with chased brass. It has a black and white horn handle, and a brass sheath. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger with an unusual, curved, iron blade topped with chased brass. It has a black and white horn handle, and a brass sheath. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger with an unusual, curved, iron blade topped with chased brass. It has a black and white horn handle, and a brass sheath. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger with an unusual, curved, iron blade topped with chased brass. It has a black and white horn handle, and a brass sheath. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger with an unusual, curved, iron blade topped with chased brass. It has a black and white horn handle, and a brass sheath. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger with an unusual, curved, iron blade topped with chased brass. It has a black and white horn handle, and a brass sheath. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger with an straight iron blade, and a horn, copper and brass handle. This example may not actually be from Sierra Leone.
A dagger-sheath, made of brass and copper with repousse decoration of a triangle and a square. It has chased brass geometric designs.
A sword made from a flat iron blade, with one edge. It has a plain wooden hilt.
A sword made from a flat iron blade, with one edge. It has a plain wooden hilt.
A short spear, with a pointed, flat, iron blade at one end, and a iron point at the other. The central section is made of wood, covered in red leather, with a central hide band.
A spear, with a pointed, flat, iron blade at one end, and a iron point at the other. The central section is made of wood, covered in fur, with raised bands of plaited grass.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This carved Ivory tusk forms part of a collection of five similar items produced from the 1850s onwards for the early trade in African souvenirs. Most were carved in coastal Congo, however they were later sold up and down the wet coast of Africa. This example depicts three tiers of spiralling male and female figures in relief.

This carved Ivory tusk forms part of a collection of five similar items produced from the 1850s onwards for the early trade in African souvenirs. Most were carved in coastal Congo, however they were later sold up and down the wet coast of Africa. This example depicts four tiers of spiralling male and female figures in relief. The curve in the piece suggests it may have been carved out of the molar tooth of a hippopotamus.

This carved Ivory tusk forms part of a collection of five similar items produced from the 1850s onwards for the early trade in African souvenirs. Most were carved in coastal Congo, however they were later sold up and down the wet coast of Africa. This example depicts three five of spiralling male and female figures in relief.

This carved Ivory tusk forms part of a collection of five similar items produced from the 1850s onwards for the early trade in African souvenirs. Most were carved in coastal Congo, however they were later sold up and down the wet coast of Africa. This example depicts four five of spiralling male and female figures in relief.

This carved Ivory tusk forms part of a collection of five similar items produced from the 1850s onwards for the early trade in African souvenirs. Most were carved in coastal Congo, however they were later sold up and down the wet coast of Africa. This example depicts four five of spiralling male and female figures in relief.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped and the pedestal has been hollowed out to store counters.

This is thought to be a womens beaded apron, made from black, beige and blue glass beads, woven to form alternating triangles. The original label supplied with the apron when it entered the British Museums collection, however, describes it as War boys dress of beadwork worn by Bai Burehs son. It came from a collection put together by Major F. H. Stone, who sold it to W. O. Oldman at the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum in 1907. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Wellcome Historical Medical Museum; W. O. Oldman [Collector]; F H. Stone

CulturalObject.Description: A circlet made form knotted grass. It is thought to have been collected by Alldridge in the late 19th century. The original label describes it as a piece worn on the heads of women and girls when mourning the death of a chief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Wellcome Historical Medical Museum; Stevens; Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Collector); Oldman

CulturalObject.Description: A necklet, or necklace, made from multiple loops of twisted grass, knotted into a circle. It was initially purchased by the Welcome Trust at an auction in 1918 and was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A prayer board, bearing Quranic scripts. Rectangular boards, such as this one, were used for teaching Muslim children the Quran. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A conical hat, made from coiled natural fibre. The outside of the hat is covered in tufts of dyed and undyed grass, arranged in a geometric pattern. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A bangle, made from elephant pad. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1918. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a number or sebe/sebbeh, or amulets, woven into her hair for ornamentation and protection. She has unusual scooped out eye-sockets: masks of this style are known from the period between 1900 and 1915. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1932. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has moulded bumps in her hairstyle, and four arches supporting a sebe/sebbeh, or amulet, for protection. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1934. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example wears a number of sebe/sebbeh. or amulets, worn around the base of her neck. The right eye of this mask looks as though it has been enlarged, suggesting it may have been used as a Gonde mask. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has particularly slanting eyes, which have been associated with Sherbro Island and the adjoining areas of the mainland. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a five-lobed hairstyle and intricate geometric patterns carved around the sides of the head. She has three scarification marks on each cheek.

A model canoe, carved out of wood, with diamond pattern carved into the prow and stern, and along the gunwales. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Unknown;Republic of Congo;Democratic Republic of Congo

CulturalObject.Description: This is a carved wooden staff, held by high status individuals. This example has a head carved at one end, with a long, segmented neck. It was originally recorded as being from the Kasai region in the Congo, however the head more resembles Sierra Leonean work. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is a wooden staff, carved in two parts that join together. The bottom half has a snake and crocodile carved in relief, and a pointed end for inserting into the top half. The top half has a rattle in the shaft, and ends in a female head, resembling a sowei mask. The mask is surmounted by an Asante-type umbrella. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1925. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Figures, sculpture; Domestic equipment; Textiles, cloth
CulturalObject.Description: This wooden carved item is listed in the British Museum records as a staff, but is more likely to be a hammock bar. It consists of a wooden bar, with a loop carved at each end. Attached to each loop is a carved head, on the left is a woman and the right a man, wearing a rimmed hat. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1931. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954. The original label reads West African ceremonial wand, carved with two heads.

This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff, held by high status individuals. This example has a female head carved at one end, resembling a sowei mask with a segmented neck. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Sothebys Auction Rooms, London, in 1933. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff, held by high status individuals. This example has a female head carved at one end, resembling a sowei mask with a segmented neck. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Sothebys Auction Rooms, London, in 1933. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff, held by high status individuals. This example has a female head carved at one end, resembling a sowei mask with a segmented neck. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, and was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff; it has a female head carved at one end, resembling a Sowei mask with a segmented neck. The staff is unusually decorated in strings of pink, black, green and white glass beads, and bares traces of blue paint. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1924. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954. The original Wellcome label reads rare Mendi chiefs staff, covered with beadwork, carved head at top.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
A bangle, made from a twisted piece of iron. It was initially purchased by the Welcome Trust at an auction in 1919 and was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, however it unusually comes with two female figures that can support the board raised above the ground. The board it attached to the figures by joining them up at each end with a wooden peg. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped and has a central hole which would have lead to a cavity in the base - now missing. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1934. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example has a hollowed out base, with a rectangular cavity for storing counters. the cavity is decorated with incised geometric patterns. There is a similar example at the Pitt Rivers Museum in Oxford, collected in the 1850s, and thought to be Vai. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is elaborately carved, with a hollowed out base, and is very heavy. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A brush, or broom, for sweeping the floor. It is made out of palm fibres which have been folded in half, and reinforced with cane. Its handle has a geometric design in dark and light fibres.This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Gledinnings Auction Rooms, London, in 1932. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954

A brush, or broom, for sweeping the floor. It is made out of palm fibres which have been folded in half, and reinforced with cane. Its handle has a geometric design in dark and light fibres. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Gledinnings Auction Rooms, London, in 1932. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A brush, or broom, for sweeping the floor. It is made out of palm fibres which have been folded in half, and reinforced with cane. Its handle has a geometric design in dark and light fibres. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A puzzle game, consisting of a length of cane. Two loops of twisted cotton string are tied to it, from a notch at either end, to a hole in the middle. Two seeds hand from each loop. It was purchased at the 1924 British Empire Exhibition in Wembley, London.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Wellcome Historical Medical Museum; British Empire Exhibition

CulturalObject.Description: This item is used like a knuckle duster, or fighting claw. Such devices have been thought to have been used by members of the so-called Human Leopards, or Leopard society, as a means of blaming the deaths of their victims on leopards. It consists of five metal claws attached to a bar. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is a wooden palette with a carved female head, used for mixing hojo, a cosmetic or medicine of white clay, or kohwoso, and animal fat. The hojo is used for painting the faces of girls being initiated into the Sande, or Bundu, societies. This mixing palette is oval in shape, and sites on a raised platform. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Glendinnings Auction Rooms, London, in 1934. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A conical hat, made from coiled natural fibre. The outside of the hat is covered in loose pieces of grass, held in place by strips of red leather. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1905. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: This is part of a loom, made from two wooden pieces, joined by a number of reed slats. The loom was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical collection (accession number: 12880,8145), before being acquired by the British Museum at Stevens auction on the 16th of August, 1908, lot number 139.

A hammock, made from natural and darkened fibres, woven to create a geometric design. The Hammock is fringed by tassels. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A skirt, made from woven, black dyed, raffia. It is ornamented with bugle beads, and bits of calabash, which would have rattled when worn. It is likely to have been part of a costume worn by dancers, or public performers. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A mask, or headdress, made from white and red cotton. It has two horns, covered in red cotton, attached to the top, and is decorated with cowrie shells. It is one of a number of masks that were purchased by the Welcome Foundation from the Stevens auction in 1908. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This pair of cattle horns are encased in red cotton covers and decorated with cowrie shells. The are likely to be part of a headdress.This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A mask, or headdress, made from white and red cotton, and decorated with circles of fur, cowrie shells, mirror and plastic buttons. It is one of a number of masks that were purchased by the Welcome Foundation from the Stevens auction in 1908, it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.Materials: Textile; Bone, ivory, tooth; Shell; Glass; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has an 11 lobed hairstyle, and is intact with its black-dyed raffia. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical three-ridged hairstyle, and appears unused. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This mask resembles a sowei mask, used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. Such masks are traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This is an usual example with four faces, though it may never have been used, indicated by its lack of holes for raffia. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a diamond shaped face, and a typical three lobed hairstyle, with two horns protruding from the back. It is complete with raffia, attached through a set of holes drilled around the bottom. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a segmented neck, a seven-lobed hairstyle, and geometric designs carved on the back and side of the head. It is likely to have the same carver as another sowei mask in the British Museum collection, numbered 1954 +23 3494. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is recorded as a Sowei Mask in the British Museum catalogue, though its painted state suggests that it might, rather, be a gonde mask. The gonde is an entertainment masker that appears together with the dignified ndoli jowei, or dancing Sowei, of the Sande society. It offers a parody of the latter by its own dishevelled appearance and undignified behaviour. The mask is often an old Sowei mask that is too decayed or damaged to be used for its original purpose, which seems likely in this case, although the gonde is often painted white, rather than blue, brown, and silver. Unlike the ndoli jowei, little attempt is made to conceal the person wearing the mask. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example seems unused, but the carving is sharp and detailed, depicting an elaborated hairstyle with rows of triangles, in high relief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1930. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This may be a gbetu mask, as part of the mens gbetu masquerader costume, among Vai, Gola and Mende people. Typically gbetu masks have a conical head piece, surmounted by a long, segmented neck with a small head on the top. The rest of the costume consists of three skirts of raffia, worn round the neck, chest, and neck. This example is unusual as it is shorter than usual gbetu masks, and does not have a conical base. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has two horns running across the head, from left to right, and a third running from front to back. There is a band of tooth-like objects running around the back of the head. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1925. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This mask resembles a sowei mask, used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. Such masks are traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a three-lobed hairstyle, adorned with a carved sebe/sebbeh or amulets. It is, however, likely unused and may have been carved for sale, rather than use. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Glendinnings Auction Rooms, London, in 1933. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This is an unusual example, with two bulbous, backwards pointing, horns and, what look like representations of segbureh/segbula rattles, adorning the head. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A kabemba, or ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example has two long, upright horns, and is decorated with pieces of cut metal strips. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A kabemba, or ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example has a single horn protruding from the top, and is decorated with pieces of strip metal. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A kabemba, or ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example has a three-lobed headdress and is decorated with strips of metal. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A kabemba, or ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example has two connected horns protruding from the forehead, and is decorated with pieces of strip metal. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A kabemba, or ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example has two horns curving to the back of the head, and is decorated with pieces of cut metal strips. It has raffia attached to it through holes drilled round the sides. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A seated female figure, carved out of wood. She has a hairstyle consisting of five bunches, and sits on chair. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, thought to have been acquired in the Glendinning Auction Rooms, London, in 1933. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A miniature sowei mask. It has pursed lips and an elaborate hairstyle. It was purchased from Stevens auction on 1933. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1933. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A wooden pillar, depicting a Janus, or two faced, sowei mask. The mask has a typical three ridged hairstyle and surmounts a segmented neck, attached to a circular base. This item was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is likely to be a Njayei, or Yasi in Bullom, society male figure, from a male-female pair; the female figure may have gone to another museum. The Njayei society is predominantly a Sherbro/Mende society that has its own source of spiritual power, called halei, that it uses to diagnose various kinds of ritual pollution and to purify those who have wittingly or unwittingly incurred pollution. A symptom of pollution is thought to be mental illness, Njayei is said to be specially empowered by its medicine to cure mental illness. It has both male and female members.

This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures, this example is shorted than other min figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. This example has a typical segmented neck, and is mounted on a circular pedestal. She has been painted black, and has residues of white paint on her neck. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1924. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any full-length carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. This example has elaborate geometric scarification on her stomach, a grey glass bead necklace, and a copper coloured earring in her right ear. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Southerlys Auction Rooms, London, in 1932. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954. The original label reads A large female fetish figure, covered with diaper ornament to suggest tabooing, the neck of bobbin type, the eyes inlaid with haliotis, and the head surmounted by a quaint Gabun head-dress.

This is likely to be a Njayei, or Yasi in Bullom, society female figure, from a male-female pair; the male figure may have gone to another museum. She is wearing a piece of cotton wrapped round the waist, and two horns around her neck. The Njayei society is predominantly a Sherbro/Mende society that has its own source of spiritual power, called halei, that it uses to diagnose various kinds of ritual pollution and to purify those who have wittingly or unwittingly incurred pollution. A symptom of pollution is thought to be mental illness, Njayei is said to be specially empowered by its medicine to cure mental illness. It has both male and female members. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1919. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is a carved wooden female figure. Her hands are resting on her hips and she has a geometric band carved into her hair. She wears a metal chain around her neck and is mounted on a circular pedestal. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any full-length carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. This example has geometric scarification on her stomach and wears an apron of green, black, and orange, glass beads around her waist. The style of carving is represented in a number of Sierra Leonean figures in museum exhibitions dated to between 1890 and 1910. This figure was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1919. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is an unusual figure, carved in light wood. She has scarification lines carved onto her stomach, and unusual hairstyle, which has been damaged, along with her right leg. There are residues of black paint, possible graphite. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A female figure, carved of wood. She is standing upright, with her hands resting on her stomach. She has a particular hairstyle with a ridge running from the front of her head, to the back, terminating in a point. As with two other examples from the British Museums collections, this ridge is accompanied by two large disc ears, and wide hips (see BM:Af.1925 -17 and BM:Af.1911-225). This example is also wearing boots.

This is likely to be a Njayei, or Yasi in Bullom, society female figure, from a male-female pair; the male figure is also in the British Museum collections, numbered BM:Af.1954.23.3667. She wears a beaded apron, and a carved necklace. The Njayei society is predominantly a Sherbro/Mende society that has its own source of spiritual power, called halei, that it uses to diagnose various kinds of ritual pollution and to purify those who have wittingly or unwittingly incurred pollution. A symptom of pollution is thought to be mental illness, Njayei is said to be specially empowered by its medicine to cure mental illness. It has both male and female members. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1919. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

This is likely to be a Njayei, or Yasi in Bullom, society male figure, from a male-female pair; the female figure is also in the British Museum collections, numbered BM:Af.1954.23.3666. The Njayei society is predominantly a Sherbro/Mende society that has its own source of spiritual power, called halei, that it uses to diagnose various kinds of ritual pollution and to purify those who have wittingly or unwittingly incurred pollution. A symptom of pollution is thought to be mental illness, Njayei is said to be specially empowered by its medicine to cure mental illness. It has both male and female members. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1919. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example shows a figure, holding a shield in one hand, and a sword, or staff, in the other. It is carved is a style that is associated with nomolis found in Kono and Kisi areas. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection and it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example has been damaged, and depicts the upper torso of a human figure, with hands clasped under the chin. It was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection and it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954. The original label notes it came from the Bambarra Chiefdom, in the Kono district.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example has a relatively indistinct form, but the figures hands can be seen clasping its stomach. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, and it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is thought to be female, and is badly worn. It was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Fosters Auction Rooms, London, in 1933. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicted a human figure, with its hands resting around the back. It has line carved around the neck, and a hole bored into the top of the head. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection and it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century.
