Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection and it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A nyayaru , or chordophone, known colloquially as a Fula violin. It is composed of a gourd resonator and dark hair stretched over a bridge and up the wooden neck. The gourd resonator is covered in scaled reptile skin, probably snake, and secured by cane pins. Is it played with a bow made from an arched split cane, with animal hair, bounded at the ends with twisted fibre. This example was purchased at the 1924 British Empire Exhibition in Wembley, London. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Leather, animal skin; Metal; Textile; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A nyayaru , or chordophone, known colloquially as a Fula violin. It is composed of a gourd resonator and dark hair stretched over a bridge and up the wooden neck. The gourd resonator is covered in scaled reptile skin, probably snake, and secured by cane pins. Is it played with a bow made from an arched split cane, with animal hair, bounded at the ends with twisted fibre. This example was purchased at the 1924 British Empire Exhibition in Wembley, London. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A rattle made out of a gourd, with a loose net of string, strung with two rows of cowrie shells. This example resembles a Mende segureh, or seghura, but is more carefully strung. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A rattle made out of a gourd, with a loose net of string, strung with multiple rows of cowrie shells, bordered with red, blue, and green, tubular glass beads. This example resembles a Mende segureh, or seghura, but is larger, and more carefully strung. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

The segureh or seghura, is a Mende percussion instrument consisting of a small calabash or gourd, surrounded by a string net, strung with small pieces of shell, or nut shell. The gourd is held by the neck in one hand, whilst the other hand pulls the net, causing the shells to clash against the sides of the gourd. It is traditionally used exclusively by women. This example uses cowrie shells, threaded onto white cotton. Other known names for this instrument are segula, segbula and segbureh. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

The segureh or seghura, is a Mende percussion instrument consisting of a small calabash or gourd, surrounded by a string net, strung with small pieces of shell, or nut shell. The gourd is held by the neck in one hand, whilst the other hand pulls the net, causing the shells to clash against the sides of the gourd. It is traditionally used exclusively by women. This example uses nutshells and animal vertebrae threaded onto white cotton. Other known names for this instrument are segula, segbula and segbureh. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Bone, ivory, tooth; Textile

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Musical instrumentss; Religious/ritual equipment, charms
CulturalObject.Description: This is likely to be a bunjue; a musical Instrument worn around the waists of dancing girls, or Sampa, initiated into the Sande (Mende) or Bundu (Temne) society. The remaining elements of the costume include a raffia skirt, string vest, and crested cap. This example has bunches of cane rods, terminating in seed pods which rattle when worn; it was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Harps like this one, are commonly known as Kru (or Kroo) harps. They are made from a spherical gourd resonator, to which is attached a Y-shaped piece of wood, fastened with fibre and gum, and wrapped in animal hide. Strings of fibre are lashed across the Y, inserted through holes carved in one side, and tied to the other. This example is, however incomplete and missing its resonator. It was purchased at the 1924 British Empire Exhibition in Wembley, London and acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. This example is made of cut seed pods, attached to a twisted fibre cord, that rattle when the dancer moves. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1924. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A bottle stopper, made out of carved wood. It is in the form of a female head, with a geometric hairstyle, and circular earrings. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A model canoe, carved out of wood. It has been stained black, after which an intricate geometric pattern was engraved into the base. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A model canoe, carved out of wood. It has been stained black and engraved, with an intricate geometric pattern, onto the base. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A model canoe, carved out of wood. An intricate geometric pattern has been engraved along both sides, and the base. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A model canoe, carved out of wood. An intricate geometric pattern has been engraved along one side, and it has a diamond-shaped prow and stern. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A wooden spoon, or paddle. It has a large circular bowl, attached to a carved twisted and knotted handle. The bowl is held by a small carved hand. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Stevens Auction Rooms, London, in 1924. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954
This is record in the British Museum catalogue as a hoe, though it is a very unusual example. It consists of a large metal blade, with an L-shaped wooden handle.

An ivory horn, with a fine red patina and three metal loops. This example has a particularly detailed mouth piece, with one full figure, and a band of human heads, carved in relief. It was bought at an auction in 1918. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Puttick and Simpsons Auction Rooms, London, in 1908. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

An ivory horn with a diamond shaped mouth piece, and a band of raised squares. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

An ivory horn with an oval mouth piece, and bands of geometric design running down the length of the horn. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

An ivory horn with a diamond shaped mouth piece, and a small handle opposite. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

An ivory horn with a diamond shaped mouth piece, and a small handle opposite. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Sothebys Auction Rooms, London, in 1932. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example has a hollowed out base, and a round cavity at one end for storing counters.
A cattle horn, covered in strips of tooled leatherwork, and attached to a carrying strap. The British Museum records describe it as a gun-powder horn, though it may also be a decorative object.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: A model canoe, carved out of wood. An intricate geometric pattern has been engraved along both sides, and the base. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs.

A helmet mask, likely to have been carved for the tourist market and not used. It resembles a Sowei mask from the womens Sande, or Bundu, society. It has two faces, one front and one back, and a three-lobed hairstyle. It has been painted black, and is highly varnished.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. The features of this example are indistinct, as it is badly damaged. There is an inscription on the base, reading WHM .

This mask resembles a sowei mask, used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. Such masks are traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a five-lobed hairstyle, surrounded by a double ring of cowrie shells, and is painted in glossy black. It is, however, likely unused and may have been carved for sale, rather than use.

A possible sowei mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical three-lobed hairstyle, with two snakes wrapped around the head. This mask may not have been used as it does not have any holes for raffia.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, with a geometric design carved along its flanks.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, and sits on a rectangular, decorated, plinth. It is complete with 49 white bean counters.

This item is used like a knuckle duster, or fighting claw. Such devices have been thought to have been used by members of the so-called Human Leopards, or Leopard society, as a means of blaming the deaths of their victims on leopards. It consists of four iron claws attached to a bar, with finger loop at either end.
A shirt made from open, knotted, plant fibres. The fibres have been dyed with yellow ochre, and the neck, waist, and wrists, are adorned with raffia, or grass, ruffles.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This interesting design is composed of eight strips, with bands of undyed, indigo, red, light blue, and yellow cotton. They are sewn together to create an intricate chequered effect. This example entered the collection from the Methodist Missionary Society, and it thought to be an early example.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a large head.

This mask resembles a sowei mask, used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. Such masks are traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a five-lobed hairstyle and is painted black, and varnished. It is, however, likely unused and may have been carved for sale, rather than use.

This is a dug-out canoe, made from hollowing out, and shaping, a single piece of wood. It has pointed ends, one of which is covered with canvas that has been painted with tar to seal it from water. The canoe has an old label fixed to it, which reads KROO CANOE USED BY THE FISHERMEN ON THE COAST IN SIERRA LEONE.
This is a wooden paddle, used for propelling and steering a canoe. It has a rounded handle, with a large, flat and wide paddle. It has been painted black.
This is a wooden paddle, used for propelling and steering a canoe. It has a rounded handle, with a large, flat and wide paddle. It has been painted black.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is particularly large, depicting a head with a moustache.
This unusual items is made of clay, and depicts a human or animal head. It has an open top, similar to some of the Nomoli heads, or mahe yafei, and an elongated face.
A tool, probably used in agriculture. It has a carved wooden handle and a forked iron head, with a long twisted neck.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. This example is typically boat shaped, and rests in a high stand. A four legged animal, possibly a pig, stands between the legs of the stand and supports the middle section of the board. It comes complete with a cotton bag of bean counters.

A cotton woven bag, storing 45 large seeds, used in playing Warri. Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. Counters are usually made out of seeds or dried beans, but have also been known to be bullets. Warri is thought to have been originally played by warriors to relax after fighting battles as other forms of entertainment, such as dancing, would make too much noise and might give them away.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a large head, with a moustache and nose ring.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is kneeling, and has a hole bored into the top of the head.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example rests its elbows onto its knees, supporting its head in his arms. The figure appears to be sitting on a stool.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is seated, and holds a cylindrical vessel.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is male, and rests his hands on what looks like a protruding stomach, or a globular object.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is kneeling, and wears a beard.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example has relatively indistinct features, and appears to be resting its elbows on its knees.

This is a headdress worn by girls initiated into the Sande society, during public dancing performances. It consists of a wooden bow, wrapped in printed cotton, with a black and beige fibre fringe. The bow is worn on the head, running vertically from the forehead, to the nape of the neck, and tied with the plaited straps.

This is a headdress worn by particular members of the Kamakowe section of the mens Wunde society among the Kpa, or western, Mende. This example consists of a dome-shaped basketry headdress, coated in clay, and painted with white and blue. Attached to the top is a large bunch of feathers, some other examples are also adorned with cowrie shells. The headdress was given to the British Museum by Paramount Chief J. W. Quee of the Kowa chiefdom in the Moyamba district, in 1959.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Ceramic; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is badly worn, and appears to be wearing a cap, slanted to one side.
A sample of un-spun, and undyed, cotton.
A spindle with a sample of spun cotton thread.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of 13 strips, sewn together to create cloth with cream, black, and brown, horizontal stripes; this warp pattern is known as kulu nyei. It was given to Bill Fagg in 1959, by Paramount Chief J.W.Quee of Kowa chiefdom in Moyamba district.
A vessel for storing palm wine, or poyo. It is made from a dried gourd, or calabash, and has a wooden neck,

A typical Mandingo gown, made from 13 narrow strips of undyed, plain weave, cotton. It is elaborately embroidered in herringbone, knot and loop stitch, in blue, gold, pink, green, and white, cotton. The embroidery is largely geometric in design; the compositions of three and four squares on the front and back, are thought to represent a compound. A small warri board can also be found low down, at the front. The term Mandingo here, is associated with Muslim elites from the north of Sierra Leone. This is a particularly early example, being collected between 1888 and 1890.
A necklace made from a string of 174 grey seed beads.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew; C. Barter

CulturalObject.Description: A brush, or broom, used for sweeping the floor. It is made from stands of palm fibre bound together with twine.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew; Harry Hamilton Johnston

CulturalObject.Description: A large wooden cylindrical mortar, with a semi-circular base. Mortars, such as this one, are often used for pounding rice.
A sample of 16 palm nuts, with remnants of the a pericarp, or fibrous outer layer, still intact.
A necklace made from a string of 98 pierced date stones.
A string of waist beads, made from palm kernel shells, ground into discs. The beads are mounted in a glass box. The associated label calls this item a Jigidah.
A string of waist beads, made from palm kernel shells, ground into discs. The beads are mounted in a glass box. The associated label calls this item a Jigidah.
Sample of bamboo fibre, still attached at one end to a short length of the original bamboo.

A hammock, made from natural and darkened fibres, woven to create a geometric design. The hammock is fringed by tassels, and is complete with stretchers, that run through a series of loops at each end of the hammock.

CulturalObject.Description: Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any full-length carved female wooden figures. The figure is holding a bowl and wears a piece of imported manufactured cloth around her waist. She has a necklace, resembling a snake, around her neck.
A possible point, made from a piece of hard stone, now very worn.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: McCormack Charles Farrell Easmon; H. H. Jackson

CulturalObject.Description: A possible point, or an axe, made from a piece of hard stone, now very worn.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: McCormack Charles Farrell Easmon; H. H. Jackson

CulturalObject.Description: A possible point, made from a piece of hard stone, now very worn.

CulturalObject.Description: This is recorded as a stone rubber or pounder in the British Museum catalogue. It is made from steatite, or soapstone.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: M. C. F. Easmon; Charles Farrell McCormack; H. H. Jackson

CulturalObject.Description: This is a carved wooden staff. It has a round base at one end, and a female head, resembling a sowei mask with a segmented neck, at the other.

This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any full-length carved female wooden figures. This figure has scarification mark on her stomach, lover back and breasts. She is wearing a pair of necklaces in black, and white, and three rows of waist beads. The figure also appears to be wearing shoes.

A hammock, made from country cloth. Country cloth is traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example uses red, black, and green, dyed cotton, as well as undyed white cotton. The central panel has raised pile, being woven from unspun cotton; this is likely to have been for comfort. Tassels run along the sides, attached to a strip of crotchet-like work. This example came to the British Museum as part of a collection of items from the Methodist Society, suggesting is may be an early example.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This examplle depicts a human head.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Fuller, Estelle W;National Art Collections Fund;Fuller, A W F [Year Acquired: 1963]

CulturalObject.Description: Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, though unusually the boat is attached to a set of four wheels. The front pair are missing.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example has a conical head, incisions around the neck and waist and appears to be holding a conical object.

A carved wooden A-Rong a-Thoma [araung etoma or Athoma have also been used] mask from the Temne raGbenle society. It has long downward pointing horns and large rounded triangular nostrils. The mouth is at the base of the mask, and the whole face is painted blue. It is worn flat on the head, along with a raffia fringe that is attached to the mask, and often comes out in pairs. The costume also includes a cape and raffia leggings.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example has unusually long arms, which resemble those of a hoofed animal.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a male figure, standing upright. He has incised cross-hatches covering his back.

A container for storing medicine, made out of a piece of horn. It has a leather cover, or lid, secured with a braided leather strap that runs through the pointed end of the horn. It was donated to the British Museum by Fode Mohammed Kabbah who collected a number of objects from Sierra Leone and Liberia.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. The mask has a typical protruding forehead, and large ears. Its has been painted black, whilst the mouth is painted a bright red and has a human tooth attached into it. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural groups in Sierra Leone.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. The mask has a typical protruding forehead, cheeks, and nose. The mask has scarification on its cheeks, and what may be an amulet carved onto its forehead. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural groups in Sierra Leone.

CulturalObject.Object: Carved Figure in World War One Uniform
CulturalObject.Description: A carved, wooden figure, representing a soldier wearing the uniform as worn by Sierra Leone troops who fought in the first World War. The uniform includes straps crossed over the chest, heavy boots and a bedroll carried upon his shoulders. It is accompanied by a detachable wooden wide-brimmed forage cap, accession number BM:Af.1971.32.15.b.

This wooden wide-brimmed forage cap belongs to a carved wooden figure representing a soldier wearing the uniform, as worn by Sierra Leone troops who fought in the first World War. The accession number of his figure BM:Af.1971.32.15.a.

This is a female figure, carved out of wood. She has an unusually elaborate hairstyle, or headdress, and an elongated body. She wears a necklace, resembling a snake, as well as a pair of shoes. She has scarification marks on her lower back. The British Museum catalogue notes that she is used for healing.
An unusual carved wooden female figure with scarification marks on her stomach and lower back. She is wearing an unusual headdress, or cylindrical hat, with a European looking bow on one side.

This unusual item is an axe-shaped piece of steatite, or soapstone, which has a figure carved into it. The figure is not unlike a typical nomoli figure, also made from steatite, with its broad nose and bulbous eyes. It is not known whether of not it is related to these items.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Religious/ritual equipment; Musical instruments; Figures, scupture
CulturalObject.Description: This is a carved wooden anthropomorphic trumpet, used by the mens Gbangbani society among the Limba and Loko people in northern Sierra Leone. It has two heads, and parts of it have been painted red. This is a highly secret object that would not normally be seen by women, children or non-Gbangbani members. It is kept in the Gbangbani bush, or grove, outside a village and brought out only for Gbangbani visitations when non-members have to stay indoors with the windows closed. It is thought to have been carved by a Loko carver.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a human head; it may have been originally attached to a body.

This is sowei mask, a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This is an unusual example, wearing a European pith helmet. She has a coin tied with twisted fibre to each ear; the one on the left reads BRITISH WEST AFRICA 3 PENCE 1943 , and the one on the right BRITISH WEST AFRICA 3 PENCE 1939 .

A carved, wooden, female figure, from Makeni. She is standing upright, with her arms resting on either side of her breasts. She is wearing waist beads, made from a piece of sting, wrapped in metal. She also has metal nails inserted as eyes and a piece of string treaded through her left ear.

A carved, wooden, female figure, from Magbaruka. She has pierced ears, and wears earrings made of red and orange beads, attached to a green thread. She is not carved out of a single piece of wood; her arms are attached with glue and nails.

This is sowei mask, a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example has a simple, but unusual design, with the hair being represented by a series of stylised segureh, or segbula, rattles, such as are used by Sande women.

This is sowei mask, a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. This example has an elaborate hairstyle, consisting of four ridges circling the head, and ending in bunches; it also has holes around the base for attaching raffia. This mask was purchased from Meneghini, who identified it as a Gola sowei mask.

This resembles a Kabemba, or Ka-bemba, mask worn during the initiation of Temne boys into the Poro society. Ka-bemba means grandfather, or forefather, and is worn by the person who leads the boys into the society bush for circumcision, and then out again. This example had a pair of horns, characteristic of Kabemba masks, but they have been broken off. It has scarification marks on its forehead, and cheeks, and a string of blue and black glass beads through a hole in its right ear.

A glass bottle, encased in red leatherwork and woven red and beige fibre, and with a leather stopper. This style of woven and bossed leatherwork resembles so-called Mandingo leatherwork, predominating among Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre; Glass

CulturalObject.Description: A glass bottle, encased in red and cream leatherwork, and decorated with a woven black and beige band. This style of woven and tooled leatherwork resembles so-called Mandingo leatherwork, predominating among Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Glass; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example depicts a figure, clasping what is either a protruding stomach, or a globular object.
A group of 13 arrows, with iron barbed arrow heads strapped to cane shafts with string. The arrows are contained in a tooled leather cylindrical case, or quiver, referred to in this entry.

CulturalObject.Description: A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
A sword, contained within a tooled leather sheath, with a black and white check cotton carrying strap. It is not certain whether this is actually from Sierra Leone.

The segureh or seghura, is a Mende percussion instrument consisting of a small calabash or gourd, surrounded by a string net, strung with small pieces of shell, or nut shell. The gourd is held by the neck in one hand, whilst the other hand pulls the net, causing the shells to clash against the sides of the gourd. It is traditionally used exclusively by women. This example uses nutshells and animal vertebrae threaded onto white cotton. Other known names for this instrument are segula, segbula and segbureh.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Bone, ivory, tooth; Textile

CulturalObject.Description: A model canoe, carved out of wood, with a circle carved at one end. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example is composed of 14 strips, each consisting of plain weave, with a band of undyed cotton, and a broad band of yellow and blue cheque. Sewn together, they create a striped effect. There are also four metal rings sewn to the back of the curtain to facilitate hanging.

Banda masks are more commonly associated with the Baga, Lauma and Nalu groups in Guinea, but have also been known to be used by Soso [Susu] people. This example has typical long horns, and has been painted blue, with white decoration. In Guinea, Banda, or Landa, masks are part of the circumcision ceremony for young boys and commonly depict a mixture of crocodile and human features. The masks are generally worn flat on the head, or sloping forward at an angle, over the face.

A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A short spear, with a pointed, flat, iron blade at one end, and a iron point at the other. The central section is made of wood, covered in bands of plaited grass and red leather. This may be a ceremonial object.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A short spear, with a pointed, flat, iron blade at one end, and a iron point at the other. The central section is made of wood, covered bands of plaited grass and leather. This may be a ceremonial object.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This is very ornate example of a 16th century carved ivory horn. The mouthpiece at the tip of the horn is depicted emerging from the fanged jaws of an animal head, following through to the body of the horn, which is covered in low relief carving. This section includes fantastical European creatures, and African animals such as crocodiles and serpents. The base of the horn is carved with the Coat of Arms of the Portuguese royal house, and the cross of Beja, the end is fitted with silver-gilt rim. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A short spear, with a pointed, flat, iron blade at one end, and a iron point at the other. The central section is made of wood, covered bands of plaited grass and red leather. This may be a ceremonial object.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A short spear, with a pointed, flat, iron blade at one end, and a iron point at the other. The central section is made of wood, covered bands of plaited grass and red leather. This may be a ceremonial object.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A powder horn, likely for storing gun powder. The horn has been wrapped in tooled leather, decorated with bands of metal. It has a brass spout attached to one end. This type of decoration is commonly known as Mandingo. Mandingo, here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a kneeling figure, with hands clasped around the front. It appears to be wearing a cap, and is covered in geometric lines, possibly representing clothing.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example represents a seated figure; its rights arm and leg are damaged.
A wooden staff, surmounted by a representation of a sowei mask.. The mask has two faces, or is Janus-faced, and a hairstyle with an Asante-style umbrella.
An amulet, or charm, made form a piece of horn, wrapped with cloth and mud, and adorned with cowrie shells.

This amulet, or charm, resembles a snake, or a whip. It is made from cotton, stuffed with organic material, or herbs, and adorned with cowrie shells on the snake head.

CulturalObject.Description: A collection of objects which were possibly used for divination. It includes a charm, or amulet, made from a piece of goats horn, and a bundle wrapped in fibre, as well as two coins, two flints, and two European brass crotal bells.

This is an imported chromium plated iron bell. Its handle is decorated with a swan inside a foliage arch. It is unknown what it was used for in Sierra Leone.
A clear glass bottle, containing a red substance. The bottle has raised lettering, reading EXCELSIOR GLORISUS MULTIBUS TERRA PARFUMEUR . The bottle has a fabric stopper.
A clear glass bottle, containing a red substance. The bottle has raised lettering, reading EXCELSIOR GLORISUS MULTIBUS TERRA PARFUMEUR. The bottle has a fabric stopper.
A Glass bottle, bearing the raised inscription PARFUMERIE DU PROGRES .
This is an imported round, flat, bottle, with a cork stopper. It is partially filled with a brown liquid substance. The bottle is decorated with a clock face.

A leather pouch with flaps decorated with tooled and painted geometric design. It has a leather loop at each corner, and one at the fastening, to which are attached leather tassels and buttons, as well as a plaited carrying strap. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo leatherwork.
A wooden staff, with a human face carved at one end. The face has an elaborated, geometrically engraved, hairstyle.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is in the form of a human head, with a large headdress, or hairstyle. it has five parallel lines leading back from centre of forehead.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This example is in the form of a human head, and has scarification marks on each cheek.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. This examplle represents a male figure, standing on a podium, and holding a bowl.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei. Thisi example is described by the Birithsh Museum records as an animal figure.

A coil weave lidded oval basket, commonly known as shuku blai. Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is made from turquoise, dark brown, orange, purple, and undyed, fibre.

A coil weave lidded oval basket, commonly known as shuku blai. Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is made from turquoise, dark brown, orange, purple, and undyed, fibre.

A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A sword, with a curved iron blade. The hilt, or handle, is covered in tooled leather. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal. The mask has a typical protruding forehead and upturned ears, and a large toothed, open, mouth. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural groups in Sierra Leone.

A sansa (Sasa in Mende), or finger piano. This musical instrument consists of a wooden block, containing a rattle, and sealed with a carved wooden lip. It has five metal keys held in place with a metal strip and cane. The instrument is played by plucking the keys; the vibrations are sent down to the piece of cane, which verberates the sound through the box, amplifying it. This example also has a rattle attached to the end made of 11 metal balls. The keys of a sansa are often made from flattened umbrella spokes.
A cylindrical leather pouch for holding bottles. It is undecorated, bar a leather button at the bottom, and the bag is closed by drawing together the top, with a braided leather strap.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has four horns, that meet at the top of the head, and are surmounted by a square sebe/sebbeh, or amulet. It has holes pierced round the bottom for attaching raffia.
A hammock, made from natural and darkened fibres. woven to create a geometric design. The hammock is fringed by tassels.

This is a particularly unusual example of the 16th century ivory Sapi-Portuguese saltcellars, showing the mixture of African and European influences. This piece depicts a number of apparent Judaeo-Christian motifs, including Madonna and child on the lid, and Daniel in the lions den, and three children in the fiery furnace, on the bowl. The Portuguese Royal Arms can also be seen at the very bottom of the base. Such items were often patronised by Portuguese traders, and produced in Sierra Leone a European market. This is thought to be a particularly early example as a label is still attached to the object, marking an examination in 1520.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Newcastle upon Tyne Antiquaries Society; George Allan ; Richard Bateman

CulturalObject.Description: One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have thick layered leather soles, with tooled brown leather straps, held together with a large black button. Mandingo was often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have thick layered leather soles, with tooled brown leather straps, held together with a large black button. Mandingo was often used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.

A double leather pouch with flaps decorated with a tooled geometric design. It has a leather loop at each corner, and one at the fastenings on either side, to which are attached leather tassels and buttons. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo leatherwork.

A double leather pouch with flaps decorated with a tooled geometric design. It has four leather loops to which are attached leather tassels and plaited leather buttons. This example has a spherical leather flask attached to it; the British Museum catalogue suggests it might be for storing gun-powder. The leatherwork on this bag is known as Mandingo leatherwork, commonly associated with Muslim elites.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example consists of 13 strips, with undyed warps, and warps in undyed, green, and blue cotton, as well as dyed magenta silk, wefts. There are also bands of undyed cotton and blue zigzags and diamonds. These come together into weft bands running the full width of the textile and large areas of cheque. This piece of cloth was made in 1960, and it can be seen on the Pathe News film real of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Phillip visit to the Bo Durbar, on the raised dais and steps where they are sitting.
A long belt, composed of 40 separate plaited strands of vegetable fibre. They have been woven together in triangular shapes, and each end is finished with a rope.

This is a Limba hu-ronko shirt; like ronko shirts, they are thought to have protective powers, and worn during dangerous activities such as hunting. Hu-ronko shirts are made from strips of country cloth, and often dyed reddish-brown with kola. Unlike other ronko shirts, they are often stamped with black motifs. This example, however, is undyed and not stamped, but recognisable by the triangular pocket and the type of cotton used. Hu-ronko shirts became popular during the presidency of Limba President Momoh, in the early 90s.
A circular Limba cap, made from two pieces of country cloth. The top of the cap is decorated with a pom-pom, and spiral embroidery in black; both have faded over time.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example is composed of 11 strips in undyed, and indigo-dyed weft cotton. The central section is woven in what, according to Venice Lamb, the Mende call stepi style (from the English word steps). The name David Tucker on the cloth is apparently that of an African employee who gave the cloth to the donor, L.Bailey.

A circular tin, covered with black leather, and decorated with inlayed geometric bands of woven black and undyed fibres. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A circular tin, covered with red leather, and decorated with inlayed geometric bands of woven black, red, and undyed, fibres. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A circular tin, covered with black leather, and decorated with a wide inlayed geometric band of woven black and undyed fibres. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A rectangular tin, covered with red leather, and decorated with an inlayed geometric band of woven red and undyed fibres. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A dagger, with a steel stiletto bladed dagger, with a reinforced blade base. It has a slim wooden handle, which bevels out in the centre, and has inlaid strips of contrasting wood and brass.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, and comes with 63 seed counters.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Henry Brownrigg; British Museum Society Board Game Fund

CulturalObject.Description: Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is composed of seven strips of cotton, machine sewn together to produce bands in combinations of cream, turquoise, yellow, blue, burgundy, and lilac.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige.
