It is composed of seven strips of cotton, machine sewn together to produce bands in combinations of pink, light blue, dark blue, black, orange, turquoise, green, and white.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is composed of seven strips of cotton, machine sewn together to produce bands in combinations of cream, yellow, black and green. There are also three bands which are decorated with supplementary weave: 1.Diamond based pattern in blue; 2.Diamond and polygon based pattern in blue; 3.Diamond based pattern in blue.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is composed of seven strips of cotton, machine sewn together to produce bands in combinations of grey, black, green, and pink. The central motif is a cheque in green and pink.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is also likely to have been machine woven. It is composed of seven strips of cotton and synthetic fibres, in beige, brown, blue, green, light blue, and cream. There are also three bands which are decorated with supplementary weave: 1.Diamond based pattern in blue; 2.Diamond and polygon based pattern in blue; 3.Diamond based pattern in blue.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is also likely to have been machine woven. It is composed of seven strips of cotton and synthetic fibres, in cream, yellow, blue, turquoise, black, and lilac. The central panel consists of a block of interwoven black and white at the top and bottom of the panel. Between these two blocks is a section of lilac and cream, which is decorated with a diamond and polygon based pattern.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is also likely to have been machine woven. It is composed of seven strips of cotton and synthetic fibres, in yellow, black, pink, and cream. it has a central panel with a green border, and a cream centre that is decorated with a black diamond and polygon based pattern, also using supplementary warp.

This is a contemporary piece of country cloth, that entered the British Museum in 2002. Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This example, however, is likely to have used imported cotton, cotton dyes, as well as synthetic yarns. It is also likely to have been machine woven. It is composed of eight strips of cotton and synthetic fibres, in cream, green, turquoise, red, brown, pink, light and dark blue, orange, and black, cotton or synthetic fibre. The central panel consists of two blocks of orange at either end, and a central cream block with a diamond and polygon based pattern in blue dyed cotton.

A stone figure, known as nomoli in Mende, carved out of steatite, or soapstone. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved. Other names that have been used for figures such as this one are pompta or mahei yafei.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This example is typically boat shaped, with rounded cavities.
A cylindrical leather pouch for holding bottles. The bottom end is decorated with tooled and painted leather, and the bag is closed by drawing together the top with a braided leather strap.
A bag, woven from raffia, or grass, with a plaid pattern. The raffia forms four groups at the top, which have been tied together to form handles. The bottom of the bag is fringed.
A bag, woven from raffia, or grass, with a plaid pattern. The raffia forms bundles at the top, which have been tied together to form handles.

An early country cloth gown, labelled in the British Museum as a durki ba gown. Country cloth is traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. It is constructed from 32 narrow bands of country cloth, with panels of indigo blue, red, and natural cream colour; they have been sewn together to form a chequered design. The neck is decorated with two strips of red felt, and the back is embroidered geometric blue and red patterns. This gown resembles Mandingo gowns, but is unusual as such gowns usually have more embroidery. The chequered design likens Mende, Vai and Sherbro kpokpo cloth, suggesting that it might rather be from the southern regions of Sierra Leone.

A very early Mandingo gown, or Kusaibi gown, with particularly detailed hand-sewn embroidery. This example is made from 18 strips woven cotton, alternating in light and dark indigo-dyed bands. The front of the gown is embellished in red, brown, blue, and white, cotton embroidered geometric patterns; the back has a central panel of stripes and zigzags. The bottom of the gown is fringed by three rows of tassels. Mandingo here, refers to gowns, such as this one, being predominantly worn by Muslim elites. This gown was thought to have been made in Liberia, however, it resembles a gown donated to the British Museum by Thomas Whitfield in 1831 that was singled out as worthy of special mention in various Synopses of the British Museum, between 1832 and the 1850s
An embroidered cap, made of undyed cotton. Its shape resembles the Bambada, or crocodile mouth, hats, from the north of Sierra Leone, used by peoples such as the Limba or Kuranko.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew; Warwick Weston,

CulturalObject.Description: A woven grass mat, with a pattern of dark brown and red stripes. This example was given to the British Museum by the Royal Botanical Gardens at Kew, London. It was originally collected by Dr Robert Clarke, who was a colonial surgeon in Sierra Leone between 1838 and 1843.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ ritual equiptment
CulturalObject.Description: A leather necklace, originally thought to be North American, however, its form is more likely to be West African, particularly Sierra Leonean. It consists of three leather sebe/sebbeh, or amulets. strung on to a leather thong. The construction of the necklace resembles Mandingo leatherwork, traditionally associated with Muslim elites.

A conical hat, made from coiled raffia work. It has a high dome, lined with a leather headband, and a wide brim, decorated with dark stripes. Is it identified in the British Museum records as a Foulah (or Fula) cap and likely to be one of the items collected by Thomas Whitfield in the 1820s.
CulturalObject.Materials: Vegetable, organic fibre; Leather, animal skin

CulturalObject.Description: A conical hat, made from coiled raffia work. It has a high, three-tiered dome, and a wide, upturned rim. It is decorated with dark brown stripes.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have thick layered leather soles, with tooled brown leather straps, held together with a large black button. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have thick layered leather soles, with tooled brown leather straps, held together with a large black button. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo.
A tooled leather quiver, with a carrying strap and tassels. It has a plaited fibre cap, and contains a number of barbed arrows.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre; Metal

CulturalObject.Description: A double leather pouch with flaps decorated with a tooled geometric design. It has a leather loop at each corner, and one at the fastenings on either side, to which are attached leather tassels and buttons. This bag was originally thought to be Native American but it, rather, resembles the type of leatherwork typical of Muslim elites in Sierra Leone, commonly known as Mandingo leatherwork.

An unusual sword, or machete, with a curved fat blade, with four ridges running along its length. The hilt is carved of wood, with two knobs, and the sheath is made from raw hide. A very similar example is known to have been collected by Henry McCormack in 1832, so this may also be of a very early date.

This is a 16th century ivory saltcellar or box. It is very ornate, with a series of seated figures and crocodiles in high relief surrounding the base. The lid is topped by a Janus head, or a head with two faces. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. In this example, the head on the lid looks particularly European. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

This is a 16th century ivory saltcellar or box. It is very ornate, with a series of seated figures and crocodiles in high relief surrounding the base. The lid is topped by a Janus head, or a head with two faces. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. In this example, the head on the lid looks particularly European. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.
A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid with brass and copper circles. This type of dagger is typical of Muslim cultures in inland Sierra Leone.

Harps like this one, are commonly known as Kru (or Kroo) harps. They are made from a semi-spherical gourd resonator, to which is attached a Y-shaped piece of wood, fastened with fibre and gum, and wrapped in animal hide. Strings of fibre are lashed across the Y, inserted through holes carved in one side, and tied to the other.

This item is recorded in the British Museum catalogue as a Kroomans character Box. It consists of a wooden box, with a hollwed-out cavity. Kru/Kran men from southern Liberia served as sailors all along the west African coast and had their own quarter, Krootown, in Freetown. This item presumably held a testimonial from a former employer, when applying for a job.

This is a 16th century carved hunting horn, depicting a series of figures carved in relief. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

This is a 16th century carved ivory bowl, on a shallow pedestal. It has geometric incised carving running in panels from the rim, to the base. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

This is a 16th century ivory saltcellar Lid. It depicts a four legged animal, potentially a chimpanzee, surmounted by a double head, or saddle. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. In this example, the head on the lid looks particularly European. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A fork, carved from a single piece of ivory. The top of the fork depicts a crocodile, and a four-legged animal biting a snake, in high relief. The central section is carved with double loops, and one can see the snake twisted through the loop, with its head poking out the top. This is likely to be a Sapi-Portuguese item; a term coined by the Portuguese in the 15th century to refer to items patronised for the European market. Such items often display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form.

This unusual item depicts a grotesque human head, with a crocodile climbing up its neck. The British Museum records refer to this as Afro-Portuguese, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. In this example, the head on the lid looks particularly European. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid and bound with bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.

A dagger, made with an iron blade, and a wooden handle inlaid and bound with bands of brass. The sheath is made from tooled leatherwork with a tassel, in Mandingo leatherwork, Mandingo here, refers to a type of craftsmanship associated with Muslim elites.
A wooden hair comb, carved in wood. It has fourteen teeth, attached to a rectangular section with three carved xs. This is attached to two arches, supported by seven pillars.

CulturalObject.Description: A belt, or girdle, made from 13 lengths of braided organic fibres, tied together with string at each end.

CulturalObject.Description: A circular coiled basket, made from dark brown and beige raffia, or grass. It is complete with a lid.

CulturalObject.Description: A wooden cylindrical snuff box, complete with a lid and a small carved bone spoon. The spoon has a carved handle, and is attached to the box with a plaited leather thong.

CulturalObject.Description: This is recorded as a garden charm. It is made form a piece of gourd that has been pierced with holes to attach knotted pieces of white cotton. A twisted fibre cord is tied through a hole in one corner, which may be for hanging it.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: A ceramic, or pottery, bowl, made from earthenware clay, and burnished with a pebble. The British Museum catalogue suggests it may also be a lamp,

CulturalObject.Description: This pierced leopards tooth is recorded as a charm, or amulet.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Religious/ ritual equiptment; Regailia; Body adornment, jewellery
CulturalObject.Description: This pierced piece of ivory has been carved to imitate a chimpanzee tooth. It is recorded by the British Museum catalogue as a charm, or amulet.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: A womens beaded apron, worn round the waist with a fibre rope. It is made from yellow, red, white, and blue, glass beaded latticework.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: A beaded womans belt, made from yellow, red, white, and blue, glass beaded latticework.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles what is commonly known as a Fula guitar, identified by its rectangular wooden body with skin stretched over the top and nailed in place. It has a small bridge, carved out of gourd, and a set of vegetable strings running up the long wooden neck.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Leather, animal skin; Metal; Vegetable, organic fibre
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles what is commonly known as a Fula guitar, identified by its rectangular wooden body with skin stretched over the top and nailed in place. It is, however, incomplete and missing its wooden neck, strings and bridge.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: A spear with a flat iron blade at one end, and a pointed iron blade at the other. It has a wooden shaft, wrapped in leather, fur, and red cotton, and decorated with strips of woven vegetable fibre.
CulturalObject.Materials: Metal; Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: A spear with a flat iron blade at one end, and a pointed iron blade at the other. It has a wooden shaft, wrapped in leather, with a fringe at one end.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: This cylindrical cap, or hat, is made from leather tooled with geometric designs. The top of the hat is fur-covered, and a long tail of tooled leather is attached to the bottom; it was decorated with cowrie shells, and four horns. The style of the hat suggests it may be an early example of a Temne or Bullom chiefs hat, complete with charms, or amulets.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Shell; Boone, ivory, horn
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves. These are attached to a leather thong, so that they can be tied to the body.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Democratic Republic of Congo;Angola;Republic of Congo;Africa
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Augustus Wollaston Franks; J. E. Oakes

CulturalObject.Description: Black and white photographic print showing a view across Freetown, looking east. The photo was taken on the 6th of January, 1906. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing crowds gathering at the entrance of St Georges Anglican Cathedral in Freetown. It was taken between 1895 and 1920. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing crowds gathering at the entrance of St Georges Anglican Cathedral in Freetown. It was taken between 1895 and 1920. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing the old railway station on Water Street, Freetown, built in 1898. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Group of women washing and drying cloths in a Freetown River. The photo was taken between 1880 and 1905.

Black and white photographic print showing the dancing sowei, known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. The dancing sowei a masquerader associated with the Sande, or Bundu, society. She is seen here wearing the full costume. This photo was taken in 1900 and it is an albumen print.
Black and white photographic print showing a group of market traders at King Jimmys Market, in Freetown. The photograph was taken between 1880 and 1905.
Black and white photographic print showing two sailing boats and a row boat off the coast of Freetown. The photograph was taken between 1880 and 1905.
Black and white photographic print showing a canoe and two sailing boats. The photo was taken between 1880 and 1905.

Black and white photographic print showing Sackville Street in Freetown. Market traders can be see in the foreground. The photograph was taken between 1880 and 1905. It was probably developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a colonial-style building, probably in Freetown. There is a sign which reads POLICE STATION. The photo was taken between 1880 and 1905 and it is an albumen print.
Black and white photographic print showing market traders at King Jimmys Market. The photo was taken between 1880 and 1905. It was probably developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a view down an unpaved avenue with mango trees, and thatched houses. The photo was taken between 1880 and 1905 and it is an albumen print.
Black and white photographic print showing a colonial-style building, probably in Freetown. The photo was taken between 1880 and 1905. It was probably developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a view of Freetown, looking East. Cape Steamer Britton can be seen in the harbour. The photo was taken in 1905.
Black and white photographic print showing women and children selling food at a Freetown market. The photo was taken in 1905. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing Samaria Chapel, one of the United Methodist churches in Freetown, before it was demolished in 1889. This photo was taken between 1888 and 1889. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print, showing a portrait taken of the chief of Petifu and some of his wives. Petifu means new town in Temne. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing Rotifunk, a Temne town in the Bumpe chiefdom. Pa Sorie, or Suro Kessebe is mentioned in the back of the photograph, who was a Loko warrior who came to Bumpe from the north. He was rewarded with the chiefship of Rotifunk for his services in defending Bumpe from the Temne of Yoni chiefdom in the 19th century. The womens auxiliary of the American United Brethren in Christ Mission made their headquarters at Rotifunk. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a two story mission house in Rotifunk, Bumpe chiefdom. Two American United Brethren in Christ missionaries, Reverend and Mrs West, can be seen on the corner of the veranda. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a three story mission girls home in Rotifunk, Bumpe chiefdom, part of the American United Brethren in Christ mission. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of mission girls, and American United Brethren in Christ missionaries, Sanford Safe and his wife. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of mission boys with an English priest, and his wife; both United Brethren in Christ missionaries. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing Reverend Daniel Flickinger Wilberforce (holding an open Bible) and his pupils at Shenge, or Shaingay, Mission School. Daniel Flickinger Wilberforce (1856-1927) was born in Imperi chiefdom to Christian parents, and was named after Daniel Kumler Flickinger, one of the early United Brethren in Christ missionaries. He was educated in Dayton, Ohio, in the United Brethren theological school, and returned to Shenge in 1878 as an ordained missionary, and principal of its mission school. Following the Hut Tax War in 1898, he was appointed Paramount Chief of Imperi chiefdom, but he was subsequently accused of involvement in cannibal murders and, although the charges were never proved, was sent into exile in Liberia. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself.

Black and white photographic print showing chief Pa Sorie, or Suri Kessebe (seated in the centre). Pa Sorie was a Loko warrior who came from the north in the 1840s to assist the Caulker chiefs of Bumpe chiefdom in wars with the Temne of Yoni. He was rewarded for his services by being made chief of Rotifunk. Pa Sorie converted to Christianity in 1892, shortly after this photograph was taken. He died in 1897. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a Loko girl initiated into the womens Bundu, or Bondo, society in Rotifunk. The is wearing the attire worn during public dancing performances. This photo was taken between 1888 and 1889. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing two young women, the one on the left is a mission girl and the one of the right is described as wife of a heathen. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself.This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of men and women resting outside a single story building. The associated writing in the album reads On the way to Mendi: the boys want to blow a bit. Blow is Krio for rest, suggesting the people in the picture might be the missions carriers resting on their journey into the provinces. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a woman wearing hojo: a mixture of white clay and animal fat used as protective medicine and a cosmetic, particularly during initiation onto the Bundu or Sande societies. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself.

Black and white photographic print showing the crowning of a king; the king was the chief of Kafu Bullon chiefdom, directly across the Sierra Leone River from Freetown. The Chiefs town was traditionally Yongro, which was where this photograph was taken. A Mamagpara dancer can be seen in the foreground on stilts. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a scene of the crowning of a native king. The king is the chief of Kafu Bullom, known as Be Sebora, or Bai Sherbro, and can be seen in the front row wearing a European top hat. The man European cloths, holding an open book, is J. C. E. Parkes, the Secretary for Native Affairs and the Sierra Leonean clergyman is Rev. Henry Boston, base in Yongro. The man, third from the left, wearing a lighter gown, is likely to be Be Same, the Paramount chief of the neighbouring Loko Massama chiefdom. The the Europeans are Dr Kavanagh of the Army Medical Department, Lieut. Bodden, aide-de-camp to the Governor, and Lieut. Lendy, of the 2nd Battalion, West India Regt. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing the crowning of a native king. The king is the chief of Kafu Bullon, known as Be Sebora, or Bai Sherbro. The man reading a book on the left is J. C. E. Parkes, the Secretary for Native Affairs. He is reading either a letter from the Governor in Freetown giving his approval, or the text of previous treaties with the Bullom. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing the crowning of a native king. The king is the chief of Kafu Bullon, known as Be Sebora, or Bai Sherbro. Musicians can be seen playing the balanji, or xylophone, and on drums; a crouching masked devil can also be seen in the centre of the ring - it may be kolloh, the masked devil of Yongro. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print of Mammy, or Madame, Yoko; the paramount chief of Moyamba. Mammy Yoko worked closely with the colonial authorities of Freetown and is described here as a queen. She is sitting in the centre, shown with members of the Sierra Leone Frontier Police. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a native palaver. Palaver is a Krio term for any kind of dispute, discussion or court case. The photograph was taken in Shenge and shows Neil Caulker and his sister leading the trail. The Caulkers were the ruling family in the Kagboro chiefdom; Shenge was the principal town in Kagboro and well as the first site or the United Brethren of Christ Mission. The photo was taken in 1889. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a Kroo village. The Kru people were originally settled along the coast in south- east Liberia, although many sought employment in Sierra Leone where a section of Freetown came to be known as Kroo Town. This photo was taken in 1889. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing Samaria Chapel, one of the United Methodist churches in Freetown. This is just before it was demolished, to make way for a new church building. This photo was taken in 1889. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing Samaria Chapel, one of the United Methodist churches in Freetown. It is in the process of being demolished, to make way for a new church building. This photo was taken in 1889. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing Samaria Chapel, one of the United Methodist churches in Freetown. It is in the process of being demolished, to make way for a new church building. This photo was taken in 1889. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing the Petifu (or Paitafoo) Chapel. Petifu was the site of a United Methodist Free Churches Mission station in the late 19th century. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of church members, in front of the Petifu Chapel. Petifu was the site of a United Methodist Free Churches Mission station in the late 19th century. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print of a large group of people, taken in Petifu, the site of a United Methodist Free Churches Mission station in the late 19th century. Rev. William Vivian can be seen in the photograph with chief Mark of Baoma; Baoma is a chiefdom, and town, between Bo and Kenema. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing the path entering Old Paitafoo (or Petifu), the site of a United Methodist Free Churches Mission station in the late 19th century. It is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of people waiting to cross a the Paitafoo, or Petifu, River. This photo is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of girls undergoing initiation into the Sande society. They are painted in hojo: a mixture of white clay, or Kohwoso, and animal fat with medicinal and cosmetic properties. This is thought to be one of the earliest photographs of girls undergoing initiation in the Provinces. It is part of a collection from an album put together by William Vivian in 1889; Vivian was a Missionary with the United Methodist Free Churches, and is likely to have taken the photographs himself. This is an albumen print.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example is composed of four wide strips, measuring 305mm in width, decorated in bands of cream, and indigo-dyed, cotton, and red thread. Sewn together they create a chequered design, bordered by bands of zigzags of red and blue. The red thread is likely to have been imported.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example consists of nine strips of weft plain weave, with undyed, and indigo-dyed, warp threads. Sewn together, they create a striped effect.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is an example of Njawi-Kpokpo cloth, used fro formal or ceremonial purposes, such as the coming out of girls, initiated into the Sande society, or more recently, in political ceremonies. This example is composed of eight strips in natural cotton, with bands of pink, blue, and red, dyed cotton wefts. The piece has a central band with lozenge motifs, flanked by solid blue weft-faced stripes.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This item may be a sample of such cloth, demonstrating various inlay motifs, such as a red and blue diamond, a blue arrow head, blue and red triangles and a sugar cane pattern, all on an undyed background.
A reed beater, used for weaving. It consists of two peices of cane, attached together with slats of fibre.

A reversible apron, worn as part of a dancers costume. It consists of a wide leather band that has been covered with cloth: it is red, white, and brown, striped on one side, and has pink embroidered cloth on the other. Two strips of leather are fastened to each corner so that is can be tied round the waist. Attached to the band are three cloth flaps: On one side they are covered in a patchwork of pink, red, brown, orange, and yellow, fabric, joined with leather strips. The other side is plainer, covered in braided blue and white cotton cord. The British Museum catalogue notes that this may be a Yoruba piece, collected in Sierra Leone.

A model canoe, carved out of wood. An intricate geometric pattern has been engraved along both sides, and the base, which are stained black. There are a number of such model boats in early museum collections from Sierra Leone; they may have been made specifically for sale as souvenirs.
Parts of a Mende loom for weaving strips of country cloth. It is made of wood, cane, and course organic fibres. It is accompanied by a spool of unwoven cotton thread.
Parts of a Mende loom for weaving strips of country cloth. It is made of wood, cane, and course organic fibres, and has a piece of partially woven cotton, measuring 100mm by 730mm.
Parts of a Mende loom for weaving strips of country cloth. It is made of wood, cane, and course organic fibres, and has a piece of partially woven cotton.

A hammock, made from country cloth. Country cloth is traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example has an elaborate design, being constructed of several strips in alternating patterns and colours. It uses light blue, dark blue, black, yellow, green, and red, dyed cotton; the central white panel has a deep pile. The hammock is supported by wooden poles, terminating in birds heads at either end. This was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection. It was acquired by the British Museum in 1954.

A piece of cloth, composed of five strips of hand woven, undyed, cotton. The central section has been embroidered with blue cotton in a geometric pattern. Five tassels adorn one end. The garment appears unfinished, but may have been used as a shawl.

Black and white postcard showing two women facing each other, labelled Susu girls. The one on the right has a number of objects woven into her hair. The photograph is thought to have been taken between 1901-1910.

Photographic print showing two men with portable xylophones, or Balangi, strapped around their necks. They are seen within an area enclosed by a low fence. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery has the same photograph, signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S., with the caption: Belanjeh Players. The Balanji is one of the principal instruments of the Mandingo, Mahommedan, people. West Africa. This image appears to be a newspaper cutting.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of men walking down a street. Five men can be seen in the foreground, playing the Balangi. The photograph is labelled hut tax palaver, suggesting it may be some sort of procession. The Hut Tax War was in 1898. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of steatite, or soapstone, figures known as Nomolis, or Mahe Yafei. They are photographed with two iron rings. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a Warri Board, supported by a four legged animal, possibly a pig. This same warri board is in the British Museum collections, numbered Af.1958.13.12. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a collection of steatite, or soapstone, heads, commonly known as Mahe Yafei. There is also a full figure, or Nomoli. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a steatite, or soapstone, head, commonly known as a Mahe Yafei. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print of a tool for transplanting rice, or a hoe. It has a wooden handle and a metal blade. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a steatite, or soapstone, figure known as a Nomoli, or Mahe Yafei. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing two Koranko, or Kuranko, mat makers. They are weaving mats of reeds or palm fonds. The photo is taking in a place called Lengekoro. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
A colour postcard of Momo Yatara, a Susu weaver. He is wearing a gown and American shoes. This may be a black and white photograph that may have been tinted. It is dated to between 1910 and 1950.
Black and white photographic print showing a young woman standing inside a large loom. The photo is taking in a place called Lengekoro. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a Kuranko woman standing next to bundles of dried elephant grass. The photograph may have bent taken in Lengekoro. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a hilly coastline, resembling the hills behind Freetown. The photograph is labelled Bunce Island so may have been taken returning from Bunce Island to Freetown, along the mouth of the Rokel River. This photo was taken pre 1946. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of people in front of a circular shelter. The British Museum records note that they are wearing American clothing. This photo was taken pre 1946, and may have been taken in a village called Ro Ponka. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of people in front of a circular shelter. The British Museum records note that they are wearing American clothing. This photo was taken pre 1946, and may have been taken in a village called Ro Ponka. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a view of circular thatched shelters. This photo was taken pre 1946, and may have been taken in a village called Ro Ponka. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a young man climbing down a palm tree, after picking coconuts. This photo was taken pre 1946, and may have been taken in a village Ro Ponka. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of men paddling a canoe; they are likely to be fishing. This photo was taken pre 1946, and may have been taken in a village Ro Ponka. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of men paddling a canoe; they are likely to be fishing. This photo was taken pre 1946, and is likely to have been taken along the Rokel River. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a the view from a river. This photo was taken pre 1946, and is likely to have been taken along the Rokel River. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a ndoli jowei, or dancing sowei. The masked dancer wears a helmet mask, trousers and a dyed black raffia cape. The mask type resembles masks of an early date, identified as Gola. The photograph was taken by Alldridge in 1899 and was published as Figure 47 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge writes of the Bundu devil: Her distinctive costume is unvarying, all Bundu devils being similarly attired, except as regards their head-piece, which admits of some slight variation. No part of the body may be visible, consequently the cloth casings of the arms and legs are sewn up at the extremities, and in each covered hand the devil carries a little bunch of twigs... Her dress is of a long shaggy fibre, dyed black, and over her head she wears a grotesque wooden mask (p.141).

Black and white photographic print showing a group of children, and two young women. The girls are all wearing lappa, or sarongs. This photo was taken pre 1941, and possibly in Freetown. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing an elderly lady, wearing a lappa, or sarong, and leaning on a stick. This photo was taken pre 1941, and possibly in Freetown. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a woman weaving a circular net for fishing. This photo was taken pre 1941, and possibly in Freetown. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a woman weaving a circular net for fishing. This photo was taken pre 1941, and possibly in Freetown. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of women fishing in shallow water, with a large circular net. This photo was taken pre 1941, and possibly in Freetown. It was developed using a gelatin silver process.
Black and white photographic print showing a view of a settlement, at Susans Bay in central Freetown. A number of fishing boasts can be seen in the harbour.
Black and white photographic print showing a view across to a European settlement, including a fort and houses. It is not known where this photograph was taken. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of three men, holding bows, arrows and swords. This photograph was taken by Alldridge and published as Figure 59 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan) with the caption War Boys, Upper Mendi.

Black and white photographic print showing a ndoli jowei, or dancing sowei. The masked dancer wears a helmet mask, trousers and a dyed black raffia cape. The mask type resembles masks of an early date, identified as Gola. The photograph was taken by Alldridge in 1899. This is an albumen print. The photograph was published as Figure 48 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan) with the caption Bundu devil with attendant Digbas.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of men carrying large bundles wrapped in palm fonds. This photograph is thought to have been taken by Alldridge. This is an albumen print. The photograph was published as Figure 4 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan) with the caption Natives carrying down produce from the Hinterland of Sherbro, in palm leaf hampers.

Black and white photographic print of a man wearing a country cloth gown and holding a staff, or spear, in each hand. This photograph was taken by Alldridge and published as Figure 65 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan) with the caption A young Upper Mendi chief. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a woman wearing a printed skirtcloth, or lappa, standing near a house. She is wearing a necklace made out of leopards teeth, and large arm cuffs on each wrist. The Brighton Museum has a copy of the same photograph, and written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 39, p.126 / Serenading - a Sophist - Upper Mendi / No. 17 / Upper Mendi Princess wearing leopards teeth necklace. Sign of being free-born / Alldridge Neg List No 17. This is an albumen print. Published as Figure 39 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing five girls with their faces painted in white clay and wearing elaborate costumes. They are likely to be recently initiated into the Sande society, and potentially sampa. The photograph was taken by Alldridge and published as Figure 45 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan) with the caption Bundu girls in dancing costume. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing the backs of the five girls photographed in BM:Af.B84.25. They are likely to be recently initiated into the Sande society, and potentially sampa. This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing five young men dressed with elaborate costumes and surrounded by a crowd of people. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery has the same photograph, and written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 38, p.126 / Poro boys in dancing costume, Juru, Gaura Country, Upper Mende / Alldridge Neg List No 44. Published as Figure 38 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). This is an albumen print.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of Mende women playing a gourd rattle, or segure/segbureh. Other people are seen around them. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery has the same photograph, and written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 37, p.122 / Playing the Sehgura - the national musical instrument of the Mendi women / Alldridge Neg List No 9. This is an albumen print. Published as Figure 37 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing four young women, initiated into the Sande society, wearing traditional hair styles which bare resemblance to those depicted on many Sowei masks. One girl has her face painted, two other girls have scarification marks over their forehead and stomach. All the girls also bear similar body adornment, or jewellery, across the chest and round the neck. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery has the same photograph, and written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 63, p.211 / Bundu [Sande] girls, Vassa Country. This is an albumen print. Published as Figure 63 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing a group of Mende women wearing different printed cloths, or lappas, and with different hairstyles. These hairstyles resemble those found on many Sowei masks. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery has the same photograph, and written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 34, p.113 / Showing some of the numerous styles in which the Upper Mende women dress their hair / Alldridge Neg list No 11. This is an albumen print. Published as Figure 34 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).
Black and white photographic print showing a group of young men wearing raffia skirts and headdresses. The photograph is labelled circumcision dance, and dated in 1936. It is an albumen print.
Black and white photographic print showing a view across the sea, towards Freetown. It was taken between 1891 and 1900. This photograph was developed using a gelatin silver process.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any full-length carved female wooden figures. This example is, however, very short for a real min figure. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness, though they have also been associated with the Sande society. This example has two topknots carved into the hairstyle, and a long segmented neck. It was originally part of the Wellcome Historical Medical Museum collection, originally acquired at Southerlys Auction Rooms, London, in 1934, and acquired by the British Museum in 1954. The original label reads a Mendi Female Fetish Figure of slender form, with bellows neck and winged headdress .

A gown, or tunic, made of fine palm fibre that has been woven into ten strips, and joined, edge to edge. It has a triangular central breast pocket with red cotton embroidery, and further embroidery along the shoulders, and on the back. Though it looks like the so-called Mandingo gowns, it appears to be a very early example, resembling an example in the Ulster Museum, collected by Henry McCormack before 1832.

Country cloth is a thick, heavy, cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished cloth. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign or wealth and Prestige. This is thought to be an example of kpokpoi, or kpokpo, cloth, relating to country cloth made up of strips of varying colours and patterns, used to make a larger, more complex, pattern. This example is composed if eight hand-woven strips in undyed, and indigo-dyed, weft cotton. Each end is bordered by a group of three blue weft bands, and in the central band there are warp blocks at regular intervals which are decorated with two natural coloured cotton diamonds in their centre.

This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has her hands placed under her breasts, a high-ridged hairstyle, and wears orange and black glass beads around her neck and waist.

This is thought to be a minsereh, or min, figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a typical ridged hairstyle and a segmented neck. She is wearing a red glass beaded necklace.
